pageElements.text:
Mazda

When Mazda brings the Skyactiv-D 2.2-liter clean diesel version of its 2014 Mazda 6 sedan to dealer lots in the second half of this year, the company will have the distinction of being the only Japanese automaker to offer a diesel in the United States. Mazda has been mum on expected fuel economy for the 2.2-liter engine but says the Skyactiv-D engine will offer twenty percent better fuel efficiency, plus "smooth and linear response" thanks to its two-stage turbocharger. Pricing is also still unannounced, but the gasoline-engined 2014 Mazda 6 starts at $21,675.

Mercedes-Benz

Mercedes-Benz isn’t about to let the Volkswagen Group have all the diesel glory among German automakers. Mercedes-Benz sells diesel variants of its E-, GL-, M-, and S-Class vehicles. The company’s current BlueTec models all use a 3.0-liter six-cylinder turbo-diesel engine. That engine is good for 22 mpg city/32 mpg highway in the E350 BlueTec, 21/31 mpg in the S350 BlueTec, 19/26 mpg in the GL350 BlueTec 4Matic, and 20/28 mpg in the ML350 BlueTec 4Matic. Mercedes-Benz has said it plans to add a four-cylinder diesel engine to the E-Class and GLK-Class lineups. And, in case you’re the kind of person who orders the most expensive thing on the menu just because: the $93,905 S350 BlueTec is the priciest car on this list.

Porsche

The Cayenne Diesel is Porsche’s only diesel model. With its 3.0-liter six-cylinder engine, it makes 19 mpg in the city and 29 mpg on the highway. Better news is that Porsche says it has a range of 546 miles between fillups. The Cayenne starts at $56,725, bucking the diesel trend in not being the most expensive model in the Cayenne’s lineup. While the diesel version costs more than the base Cayenne, it sets owners back less than the S, S Hybrid, GTS, Turbo, and Turbo S versions of the SUV.

Ram

Ram made waves this month when it announced that it will bring a diesel engine to its half-ton 1500 pickup starting in the third quarter of 2013. This will make Ram the only brand to sell a light-duty pickup with a diesel engine, which makes us wonder if other carmakers might follow suit in the near future.

Volkswagen

Volkswagen isn’t shy about its love for diesel. The Volkswagen Automotive Group is responsible for fully half of the light diesel cars sold in the United States, including the only diesel convertible available here. VW offers TDI Clean Diesel versions of the Beetle, Beetle convertible, Golf, Jetta, Jetta SportWagen, Passat, and Touareg. Excepting the Touareg, VW’s TDI models all share a 2.0-liter, four-cylinder engine that makes 28 to 30 mpg in the city and 40 to 42 mpg on the highway, depending on the model. Range between fillups for the diesel Beetles is 418 miles; for the Golf and the Jetta, it's 444 miles; for the Jetta SportWagen, it's 431; and for the Passat, it's 566 miles.The Touareg TDI, which makes use of a larger, more powerful engine, makes 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway and offers a range between fillups of 546 miles.

The price for Volkswagen’s TDI is lowest on the Beetle Convertible, where a diesel engine will set buyers back an extra $2,900, and highest for the Jetta sedan, which costs an extra $6,335 with a diesel engine.

Plus, Trucks from U.S. Automakers

In addition to the passenger cars we've just listed, there are also several heavy-duty pickup trucks on the market that use diesel power because of its superior towing capabilities. The Chevrolet Silverado 2500 HD and 3500 HD, Ford F-150 Super Duty, GMC Sierra HD, and Ram 2500 HD and 3500 HD and 3500, 4500, and 5500 Chassis Cabs all come with diesel engines.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: We’ve all been there: driving down a dark country road minding our own business, when we crest a hill and are suddenly blinded by an oncoming car’s high beams, the driver too slow or too inconsiderate to turn them off in time to spare us. It’s annoying, sure, but it’s a problem we’re stuck with, right? Wrong. Volvo is here to save the day.

Volvo introduced its refreshed-for-2014 S60, V60, and XC60 models at the recent Geneva Auto Show and the cars are packed with new technology, including Volvo’s active high beam control system, which automatically adjusts the car’s high beams to spare oncoming drivers from the glare.

The technology works by using information from the camera already installed near the rearview mirror for detection and automatic braking. When the camera spots a car or motorcycle in the path of the high beams, it sends that information to a projector module mechanism in the headlamp, which uses small pieces of metal to shade out only the necessary parts of the high beams, leaving fellow drivers unperturbed and maintaining your clear view of the road ahead. Volvo says the technology is so accurate that it can shade out the correct portion of the headlights with only a 1.5-degree margin.

Volvo hopes the technology will keep drivers safer by allowing them to spot and avoid vulnerable road users like pedestrians, cyclists, and animals even in situations when they would normally have to turn off the brights and decrease visibility temporarily.
The high beams come as part of the $2,100 technology package on the S60, S80, XC60, and XC70. The active high beam control system will be available on the S60, V60, and XC60 this spring.

title: 2014 Volvo Will Brake for Cyclists
promoTeaserSmall: When a bicyclist swerves into your path, Volvo's technology will detect it and apply full braking.
promoTeaser: When a bicyclist swerves into your path, Volvo's technology will detect it and apply full braking.
metaTitle: 2014 Volvo Will Brake for Cyclists - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Volvo Pedestrian Detection with Full Auto Brake
Volvo Pedestrian and Cyclist Detection with Full Auto Brake
metaDescription: 2014 Volvo Will Brake for Cyclists: Read about Volvo's newly added cyclist detection safety technology for 2014 models on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: At the Geneva Auto Show this week, Volvo announced what it's calling a worldwide first: Pedestrian and Cyclist Detection with full auto braking. As its name suggests, it will fully apply the brakes for you to keep you from hitting bikers or walkers who suddenly appear in your path. Here’s technology that can’t come quickly enough for bicyclists: according to Volvo, 50 percent of all cyclists killed on European roads have collided with a car.

The new technology is going to be added to 2014 models equipped with Pedestrian Detection with full auto brake—a system that first came out on Volvos in 2010. Volvo’s original brake-support technology was introduced in 2006, so the automaker has been at it for a while.
Models that will get the new system include the 2014 S60, XC60, XC70, and S80, Volvo said.

How It Works

The system includes a dual-mode radar unit integrated into the grille, a high-resolution camera in front of the interior rearview mirror, and a control unit. The radar detects objects and calculates their distance from the car. The camera watches the motion pattern of cyclists and pedestrians. It’s possible now because quicker vision processing and advanced software allow Volvo’s detection technology to be applied to cyclists and not just cars. The cyclist needs to be headed in the same direction as the vehicle. If a bike swerves out in front of the moving car, an instant warning sounds, and full brakes are applied automatically.
Volvo marketing chief Doug Speck says the new tech is another step toward Volvo’s “long-term vision to design cars that do not crash.”

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Some motorists have been alarmed to hear of a proposed National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) rule that would require event data recorders (EDRs), colloquially known as black boxes, in all new light cars by September 2014. The boxes are designed to aid carmakers and regulators in engineering safer cars, but the rule has raised the hackles of drivers who worry that mandatory EDRs could lead to government tracking and snooping into driving habits.

Most new cars already host black boxes—96 percent of model year 2013 cars have them under the hood, according to NHTSA. EDRs are small, usually about the size of a deck of cards, and automatically save data from the five to ten seconds before an airbag-deploying crash, which can be used by regulators and automakers to help engineer a safer fleet of vehicles.

What a Black Box Does

The boxes record dozens of different data points, including the speed the car was traveling before a crash, if the brakes were applied, whether steering was erratic, and whether a seatbelt was in use at the time of impact. They also record airbag readiness, crash forces, and state of engine throttle. This data gathering is part of the impetus behind the rule. Carmakers say that the data thus collected can help them engineer safer vehicles since they’ll know more about how their cars respond during crashes.

Research isn’t the only possible application for EDR data. It has already been used in court cases involving traffic violations, perhaps most notably in a case involving former New Jersey governor Jon Corzine. Corzine was a passenger in a car that crashed while traveling 91 mph in a 65-mph zone, according to the car’s EDR.

Privacy Objections

It’s the rare federal rule that doesn’t incite at least a little ire, and this one is no different. The black box rule has raised privacy concerns despite NHTSA’s best efforts to assuage them. Some of the chief concerns are questions about who would have access to the data and when and for what purposes. Privacy activists want to ensure that car owners will have access to the data and control over other parties' access to it. NHTSA has said that it would only seek to view the data with the express permission of owners, but notes that the legal authority to regulate those privacy issues rests with state and federal governments. Only about a dozen states currently have legislation regulating EDRs.

What's Your Take?

Are you concerned about the privacy implications of black boxes in your car, or do you think the knowledge gained from the data is worth it?

title: Notorious Women: Gloria Swanson
promoTeaserSmall: She was movie royalty. Plus, her speed demonry behind the wheel inspired the film "Danger Girl."
promoTeaser: She was movie royalty. Plus, her speed demonry behind the wheel inspired the film "Danger Girl."
metaTitle: Notorious Women: Gloria Swanson - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Read more in our series on women in automotive history—Notorious Women: Gloria Swanson. She was one of history's most celebrated movie stars, who loved to drive fast and spend money on cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Gloria Swanson

In 1916, movie star Gloria Swanson was a mere seventeen years old, and her fiance, Wallace Beery, was teaching her to drive. She just loved it and compared it to the thrill she got horseback riding as a kid. She describes how she came to make the film The Danger Girl for Keystone:

"One morning when I was driving to work, I found myself answering some command from deep inside me and started putting on speed until I heard Wally screaming in the seat beside me. I tore past the Keystone gates and almost missed the turn into our lot across the street. I roared up to the bungalow, jumped on the brake, and stopped on a dime.

"When the dust settled, half a dozen people ran out of the building. They couldn’t believe it was Baby Gloria behind the wheel. They hadn’t had such a shock since they first saw me smoke a cigarette." Someone joked that it would be a funny way to start a movie, and within the week, a rough script was ready.

From the Sublime Bentley to the Downmarket Toyota

Like many other Hollywood actors of her generation, Gloria was a wealthy woman and had money to burn, which she spent with abandon on clothes, houses, and lavish cars. Gloria owned a 1929 Model A Ford station wagon, a 1920s-era Leach, a 1949 Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith, a 1963 Bentley S3, a 1965 Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow III, a 1970 Vauxhall Viva, and a 1970 Toyota Corona Mark II, which was a replacement for one of her chauffeur-driven Rolls-Royce cars. Her most famous car was a Lancia upholstered with leopard skins, which likely inspired the leopard-upholstered 1930 Isotta-Fraschini that belonged to her most famous character, Norma Desmond, in the 1950 classic Sunset Boulevard.

images.caption: Gloria Swanson (1899-1983) with an exotic-looking custom Leach, built in Los Angeles in the 1920s. The car is said to have been powered by a big six-cylinder engine designed by Harry Miller.
Gloria's first husband, Wallace Beery, taught her how to drive before they were married, which eventually led to making the film "The Danger Girl."
Gloria had chauffeur-driven cars but was known to drive herself with the chauffeur sitting next to her.
The car that co-starred in "Sunset Boulevard" was a 1930 Isotta-Fraschini. It once belonged to American socialite Peggy Hopkins Joyce, who received it from automobile magnate Walter Chrysler.

metaDescription: Read our interview with ESPN's motorsports reporter Jamie Little, who talks about her new co-authored book, Essential Car Care for Women. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: On a rainy Friday night in Las Vegas, Jamie Little sits at a table in a casino's sports bar, where buckets are catching drips from the roof. Tomorrow she will do an ESPN telecast from the nearby speedway, but now she's signing copies of Essential Car Care for Women, which she co-authored with Danielle McCormick.

For the occasion, Little has dressed stylishly in a canary jacket and cobalt jeans, complemented by chunky jewelry. Eighteen hours from now, she’ll be reporting from the clamor and stench of the pits, all delicacy and flair being surrendered to flame-retardant ESPN overalls and cumbersome headphones.
The book signing is another kind of action, and she appears to love it. “How’re you guys doing?” she says, pen at the ready in her slender left hand. “What’s your name?”
Fans in town for the NASCAR race ask her to pose with them for photos. Then they walk over by the slot machines and look at the inscription. “I just met a star!” one man says.
The establishment’s manager picks up a microphone to remind patrons not to miss out. “That’s ESPN reporter Jamie Little signing her book next to the lobster tank,” he says. “Ten dollars for a copy!”

The next morning we meet at Las Vegas Motor Speedway, and Little explains how co-author Danielle McCormick approached her about collaborating. It was to be a more comprehensive version of a car care book McCormick had written that was published in Great Britain. Their book takes the viewpoint that not every woman who has a car "also has a reliable man in her life."
As Little writes in her introduction, "It’s all just a matter of education, and it’s time for a change, ladies!"

From a basic lexicon, sort of a Devil's Dictionary of automotive lingo, to the process of chaining up tires for winter driving in the mountains, Essential Car Care for Women is worthy of Little's claim that it belongs in the glove box along with the owners manual. You don't have to be a woman to benefit from its clear and basic instruction, either.

Don't let it be your only reference material, though, and take the text with a grain of salt: the contention that flat tires come from deflated inner tubes (on page 21) overlooks the fact that tubeless tires became standard equipment in 1955. Possibly it's an error introduced when that part of the book was translated from British to American English, although McCormick points out that vintage cars' tires might still contain tubes.

Never mind, because this is a "visual book," as Little reminds us, and the pictures really do tell the story. It's especially well designed, with good illustrations and how-to photos in a style reminiscent of This Old House. Little demonstrates how to change a tire, use jumper cables on a dead battery, and even keep your poise when managing the aftermath of a fender bender. The book is very helpful for readers who want to understand the basics of how their car works but have been afraid to ask. Case in point: the clear, illustrated explanation of the habits of a four-stroke engine. It takes you from intake to exhaust and demystifies what happens inside those cylinders to make your car go. With plenty of other similarly helpful explanations, Essential Car Care for Women will give you more confidence when talking about and dealing with cars.

The Mitsubishi Eclipse convertible seen in the photos was a rental, specifically chosen because it's "kind of girly," she says. But there was another factor. "Because I cover NASCAR, I didn't want it to be any of the brands that compete [on the tracks], because I don't want to play favorites." Unlike Toyota, Mitsubishi never made it to NASCAR.

Beyond the most practical aspects of car care, the books larger usefulness lies in the way it gets you thinking about cars, which is something Little has done a lot of since joining ESPN in 1998. She speaks of the "adrenaline rush" of giving live updates from the pits and interviewing the winning driver in Victory Lane.

Her dedication is so profound that in 2012 she worked until she was thirty-six weeks pregnant. Her son, Carter, now seven months old, recognizes his mother's voice on TV and loves the hum of racing, a taste Little says was acquired in utero. "I may have created a monster. He's going to love cars, for sure."

When Little was a girl, she says, she was mesmerized by anything that "made noise and went fast." Her enthusiasm led her to this point. She admits that sometimes she finds herself thinking about being the first woman in the broadcast booth calling the play-by-play for major races.

Then she always reconsiders, thinking of the irresistible action on her favorite tracks at Bristol, Tennessee, and Talladega, Alabama. "The great thing about my job is being in the middle of it. I'm where everybody wants to be. I can touch the tires and smell the gas. Being in a booth, to me, is just kind of stale."
So when you look up from the pages of Essential Car Care for Women, keep watching for Little’s familiar ponytail and insulated fire suit as she produces more stories from pit road.
Essential Car Care for Women comes out in April, priced at $16, from the woman-oriented publisher Seal Press.

pageElements.text: If you've ever thought about taking cleaning and waxing your car into your own hands but have not known where to start, now could be the time to make the leap. It's officially spring, so the thought of being outside shouldn't leave you shivering, and your car is probably in need of some loving attention. For those of us in the north, that's especially true because our cars have been coated in a fine layer of slush and salt all winter.
I'm going to walk you through the steps to a shiny car.

1. Shop for the Right Tools and Equipment

First, get your hands on some of the great products out there that make it easier. I'll lay them out as we go through the steps. You should always read the instructions for any products you use on your car to make sure you're using the right one for your vehicle and applying them correctly.

2. Start with a Wash

Washing your car regularly is an important part of car maintenance. It can help prevent rusting and will wash off compounds that could otherwise bind themselves to your car's paint and cause damage. If you're washing your car yourself, make sure to use the proper cleaning agent. Household detergents can damage a car's paint and cause premature rusting, so make sure you use a cleaning product designed specifically for cars. Also be sure to use wash mitts, sponges, and towels designed for use on cars. Household sponges and towels could scratch the car's paint.
Of course, if you're not inclined to wash the car yourself, professional car washes all use soap that is safe for cars.

3. Step Up to a Deep Clean

If you're really looking to get in your car's good graces, take the time to do some deep cleaning. There are plenty of products out there for cars in every state of disrepair. If you haven't waxed or polished your car in a while (or ever), you may want to start by using auto detailing clay. This will remove contaminants that are clinging to the surface of the paint. Auto supply stores sell clay bars, lubricant, and microfiber towels for this.

Spray a layer of lubricant on the surface of the car, then gently rub a piece of auto detailing clay over the lubricated area until it glides smoothly.This means the clay has picked up all the grit it can from the car's surface. Next, dry off the area you clayed with a microfiber towel. You should be able to notice that the "clayed" areas feel smoother than the areas you haven't clayed yet.

image.caption: Polishing can be easier with a power tool.

pageElements.text:
4. Polish

The next step in a thorough car detailing is to use paint cleaner to remove imperfections that are lurking under the paint's surface. Paint cleaner requires somewhat forceful application, so if you're not interested in doing all that work by hand but still want the benefit of having used a cleaner, look into buying a dual action polisher. These tools cost more than $100 but they're big labor savers; they have oscillating heads that can work in the polish with minimal input from you. Unlike traditional circular polishers that the professionals use, these tools won't damage your paint if they're not used properly, so they're a good choice for beginners. If your car has a scratch deep enough to penetrate the clear coat, you should take it to a professional to have it fixed.

5. Wax On, Wax Off

Once you've polished, you're ready for waxing and finishing touches. If you're waxing your car by hand, use a foam sponge to apply a thin layer of wax to the car's surface. There's no need to lay down a thick coating; this will only make the wax harder to wipe off without providing any real benefit. If you'd rather not do this by hand, you can use an oscillating tool for wax application, too. Once you've laid down a thin layer of wax, wipe it off and admire your handiwork.

The whole wash-and-wax process might seem like a lot of effort, but it will protect your car from damage much better than a plain old wash, and your car will look so good. Even better: you should only need to polish and wax your car once or twice a year, with minor maintenance between deep cleans.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It's been another long, gray winter here in Michigan. Not exactly the kind of weather that inspires people to spend hours outside detailing their cars. But it seems like spring is almost here (knock on wood), so in between weeding your garden and having picnics in the park, take some time to spring clean your car. It may not sound like fun, but performing regular maintenance on your car can extend its life. Here are a few things you can do to help your car recover from winter.

1. Clean the Winter Off

Washing your car regularly is important in helping to avoid rust and paint damage from bonded-on debris. Northerners should be washing your car all winter to minimize the damage from the salt and slush we drive through all season, too. But a deeper cleaning once the weather warms up is a good idea and can help keep your car's paint protected throughout the summer. For detailed tips on how to have your car shining like new, click here.

2. Check (Maybe Change) Tires

If you have snow tires (and we really think you should), make sure to switch back to all-seasons for the warmer months. Winter tires are made with compounds that are specifically designed for cold temperatures. They won't perform their best if you ask them to work in warm weather, nor will their massive treads do you much good on warm, dry roads.
Related story: 5 Rules of Tire Shopping

When you put your all-season tires back on, check the treads to make sure they are wearing evenly and haven't worn down too much. Also make sure all your tires (including the spare) are inflated properly. You can check inside the doorjamb for recommended tire pressure.

3. Give It a Seasonal Once-Over

Jean has already given us some easy tips for seasonal checks for your car, but here's a quick refresher: check the car's fluids (coolant, windshield washer fluid, brake fluid, and oil), and check for damage and wear to rubber connecting hoses, tires, and windshield wipers. It's a good idea to perform this check twice a year, and spring is a good time to start. Coolant, washer fluid, and oil may need to be topped off. If it has been more than 5,000 miles since your last oil change, it might be time to change it. If your brake fluid isn't fairly clear, it could be time to have that changed, too.
This may seem like a lot of work, but it won't be time-consuming, and it will make your car look, feel, and work better. You'll be glad you did it. Happy spring!

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Dorothy Paget

Dorothy Paget was a filthy, filthy rich British aristocrat who hated men. No, really. She did. Dorothy was and is probably best known for her racehorses, but she also owned racing cars. In 1930, she bought three Bentleys belonging to Tim Birkin, a famous racing driver, and financed his project to construct five supercharged Bentleys for racing. This resulted in a partnership that lasted for three years, and the Blower Bentley, which never won first place in a single race and incurred Walter Owen Bentley's displeasure. (Bentley was against supercharged engines.)

According to Quintin Gilbey, author of Queen of the Turf: The Dorothy Paget Story, Dorothy was known as the "richest unmarried woman in Britain." She also may have been one of the more eccentric ones. Dorothy slept during daylight hours, waking at night to eat breakfast and place exorbitant bets, sometimes on races that had already ended. When she went to the theater, she bought two seats (one for herself and one for her purse). She always wore the same coat and hat when she went to the racetrack, and she lived in fear that her car would fail her after her Rolls-Royce broke down on her way to a race. And doesn't it just make sense that she would be driving a 1929 Mercedes-Benz SSK roadster, the perfect high-powered missile for looking good in Germany on the cusp of the Nazis?

images.caption: Dorothy wore the same hat and coat to all her race events out of superstition.
Supercharged Bentleys were another type of thoroughbred she backed.
Tim Birkin in the Blower Bentley
Mercedes SSK roadster was one way she spent her considerable cash.

Helle Nice

Helle Nice lived a fast life both in and out of the car. She was born in 1900, daughter of a French postman, under the name Mariette Hélène Delangle. Her first career was as a dancer in the music halls of Paris. Then, in 1929, she entered and won the all-women's Grand Prix at Montlhery, France, driving a French Omega Six racing car. That was only a prelude to several years of competition in mainstream racing against male competitors. She toured U.S. racetracks in a Miller in 1930 and raced a Bugatti Type 35C and an Alfa Romeo 8C Monza in Grands Prix all over Europe in the years before the outbreak of World War II. She set speed records and partied hard with some of Europe's wealthiest personalities.

It all began to change for Helle in 1936. Driving an Alfa Romeo Monza in the Sao Paulo Grand Prix that July, she hit a hay bale, and her car became airborne and killed several spectators. Helle was thrown from the car and landed on a soldier, who died from the impact but broke her fall, saving her life.

After that, despite occasional amnesia, she continued to drive, notably in rallies. In the Chamonix Rally, she was co-driver to Baron Huschke von Hanstein. After World War II, on the eve of the Monte Carlo Rally, Grand Prix racing driver Louis Chiron publicly accused her of being a Gestapo collaborator. This accusation was never proved, but nevertheless she became persona non grata.

She died, alone and shunned, in Nice in 1984, but her colorful story has not been completely forgotten: a biography, Miranda Seymour's Bugatti Queen: In Search of a French Racing Legend, was published in 2004.

Josephine Baker

Josephine Baker, like Helle Nice, enlivened the Paris of the era between the two world wars. Both started as music hall performers, but whereas Helle went in the direction of racing, Josephine gained lasting renown as a performer, a dancer, a film star, a French Resistance fighter, and, eventually, a civil rights activist who spoke at the 1963 March on Washington.

Born into poverty in St. Louis, Josephine traveled to Paris in 1925 to appear as a member of a Harlem revue. She met with instant success in Paris, soon becoming a headliner and performing at the Folies Bergere. She became a legendary figure who collected exotic pets, inspired artists, and socialized with the likes of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Pablo Picasso.

Her flashiness was part of her charm. Josephine raced through the streets of Paris in an extremely arty 1934 Delage D8-15 cabriolet. Later, she lived in a chateau in the south of France, married a band leader, adopted twelve children from countries around the world, and ran through her money. Late in life, she was taken up by Princess Grace of Monaco and was in the midst of a comeback when she died suddenly, in 1975. She was the first American woman to be buried in France with full military honors, a tribute to her contribution to the French Resistance and to the love France had for this singular woman.

promoTeaser: New Michigan law forbids teen permit holders from using cell phones when they're behind the wheel.
metaTitle: Michigan Teens, Hang Up and Drive!  - JeanKnowsCars
metaDescription: Michigan Teens, Hang Up and Drive! Read about a new law that bans teen drivers from using cell phones behind the wheel. It's in Michigan, and it's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Lately, when I am driving down the road and tempted to pull out my phone, I think about Bonnie Raffaele.

I never met the woman, but she lives in Michigan, like me, and she had seventeen-year-old twins, as I currently do. One of those twins, her daughter, Kelsey, was talking on the phone while driving in January 2010. Unfortunately, the roads were icy and she was an inexperienced driver. Her last words to the person on the other end of the line were, "I'm going to crash." Even though she was only going about 35 mph, she died instantly.
I think about Bonnie Raffaele because what happened to her daughter happens all too often out on the roads, and it completely sucks.

Tiger Mom

Bonnie didn't just curl into a fetal position and never move again, which is probably what I'd do and would be understandable. Instead, she started an initiative that culminated in the passing of Kelsey's Law in the state of Michigan. As of the end of March, teen drivers in my state can't use electronic devices, including phones, while behind the wheel if they are in the permit phase of their driver's licenses.

Here's a photo of Bonnie and family with Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, celebrating the signing into law of SB 756, Kelsey's Law. Bonnie got everybody from AAA Michigan to the Brain Injury Association of Michigan behind her, along with student, police, and safety groups and a comprehensive list of state representatives from both sides of the aisle.  And rightly so. Because really, how can we say we are helping teenagers be safe drivers if we turn a blind eye to texting and phoning habits while they drive?

This Happens Way Too Much

In Michigan, more than 8,000 accidents have been blamed on cell phone use in the past ten years. Bonnie Raffaele so clearly doesn't want this to happen to any other family that she goes and talks to school groups and shows them her child’s example. Photos of the bright-eyed, happy-looking schoolgirl contrast with the charred wreck of Kelsey’s Pontiac Sunfire, which was T-boned by a Dodge Durango while she was talking on the phone and not giving her full attention to driving.

Who knows how many more teenagers are going to crash because of cell phones? At least in the state of Michigan now, those with Level 1 or Level 2 licenses will have to go without the texts and phone calls while they're driving. A Level 1 holder has taken the comprehensive first part of the required driver education course but needs to complete at least thirty of the fifty required hours of supervised driving before going on to Level 2. At Level 2, a student has taken the second part of the driver education course and is putting in the remainder of his or her fifty hours of supervised driving before qualifying to take the driving test and get a "real" license.

It seems like a complete no-brainer that phones and electronic devices should be specifically excluded during those hours of learning out on the road. Let's hope this will solidify into a habit for the teens who are now subject to this law.

Taking That Pledge

If you're nodding in agreement about rules for teenagers, how about a quick look in the mirror? I have been silencing and stashing my cell phone while I drive for about a week now. It has helped me rediscover the feeling of looking far down the highway and focusing on the traffic, the road signs, and the experience of driving. I can feel how much better I'm driving with no possibility of electronic distraction. Hey, people in the lanes around me: You’re welcome!
Besides, I have seventeen-year-old twins in the car, and I want to honor Bonnie Raffaele—who says, "I cry every day and I probably will for the rest of my life"—by setting a good example.
How about you? Do you have the strength to put the phone down and drive, like you used to do back in the day before there were cell phones?

At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. pageElements.text: Everyone loves to go to the New York International Auto Show, the last big international show of the season, because it's in New York City. I'm not immune.

It always opens right around Easter break, so it's a very popular place to take the kids, in a town where cars are typically yellow and it costs money to ride in them. The New York show is also the place where kids know they're going to find supercars. Rolls-Royce, Bentley, Porsche, McLaren, Mercedes-Benz, Lamborghini, Ferrari—all the dreamy cars are there.

Traditionally, the New York International Auto Show has been the showcase for the European carmakers. They not only like to launch world previews in New York City, but they also bring cars that were just revealed in Geneva in early March that have yet to be seen in the U.S. One example was the Rolls-Royce Wraith, which was an absolute stunner, as you see here.

The star of the show came from Detroit, surprisingly. General Motors split its big model news by revealing the 2014 Corvette Stingray in Detroit and holding the spectacular 2014 Cadillac CTS for a New York debut. Sadly the entire GM exhibit was tucked away in a remote hall, away from the razzmatazz of the rest of the show. They ought to rethink their strategy of having an exclusive place to show their cars and move back where all the action is.

The second really big piece of news, amusingly enough, was the central vacuum in the 2014 Honda Odyssey minivan. The van itself got a mild refresh, but the on-board vacuum made it to national television. Why didn’t somebody think of this ten years ago? you ask. They did: the American Honda Motor Company people all thought it was a good idea, but the Japanese rejected the idea out of hand every time it was brought up. American Honda finally figured out that culturally, women do the cleaning in Japan, and here in the U.S., men typically clean the cars. In any case, its time has come, and Honda made a deal with Shop-Vac for its vacuum.

New York is a cozy show that can be visited easily in a day. Despite the fact that there are typically very few big launches, there’s a disproportionate number of European executives who show up with their entire families and continue on to vacations.

I like to go to New York because I live on a farm, and getting to New York to look at the cars means I can take in a Broadway show. We've done that frequently. Every one I have seen has been right in the middle of the New York Auto Show. I didn't get to any Broadway shows this year, but I did go hat shopping.

This was my big chance to meet up with two famous milliners whom I had been dying to meet for the past year: Jasmin Zorlu, who brought her rolling hat show to my hotel room, and Barbara Feinman, shown at right, who has been making hats in the back of her little hat store at 66 East Seventh Street since 1998. Luckily, my husband and I drove with JKC videographer Scott Allen in Automobile Magazine’s Range Rover Evoque, a Four Seasons long-term test car, so I had room for "a few" purchases.

pageElements.text: People think it’s amazing that we drive from Michigan to the show, but we do it every year. I love the road trip, and it’s a rare opportunity to hang out with my husband and not be in a big hurry. And if we hadn’t driven, well, I wouldn’t own six new hats.
And, yes, we got it all on video. Stay tuned to Jean’s Driveway for the road trip, coming soon.

pageElements.text: Tumwater, Washington—"Any rally co-driver who tells you he is never scared racing in the woods is either lying or crazy," legendary co-driver Tom Grimshaw once said. He should know. Grimshaw won this year’s national championship riding shotgun in John Buffum’s hair-raising Audi Sport Quattro. He has been seen, after a particularly tense run through the forest, oozing out of the 500-horsepower Quattro’s front seat, trying to light two cigarettes at once with eyes crossed and holding the seat of his racing coveralls.

I was scared like that here. Good thing, too. After a couple of years of interesting (and occasionally successful) rally rides, I was beginning to think that, if Grimshaw was to be believed, I had a serious problem.

I had humbly discovered there were guys out there who could give me a better ride than I could give myself, and it didn’t scare me to ride with them. I became hooked on the sport and spoiled on the speed, which eventually landed me a hot offer for the Olympus Rally, the first American rally on the world championship schedule in twelve years.

Or maybe it wasn’t such a hot offer. This would be a pace note rally, requiring constant and precise communication between driver and co-driver. And the proposed driver, Nobuhiro Tajima, president of Suzuki Sport in Japan and Japan’s perennial rallycross champion, didn’t speak English.
Sure.

"Mr. Tajima understand right and left and numbers in English," coaxed Tajima’s front man, Kenzo Sudo. Okay, so we could buy someone’s pace notes if he used a number system instead of actual descriptions, like "fast right, easy left" and so forth, to define the speed of the turns. But calling out simple lefts and rights and high-speed crests would be one thing. How was I supposed to explain menacing stacks of logs and killer ruts and washouts and 1,500-foot dropoffs?

Truth be told, I was really more interested in whether Tajima could deliver a class win. And that looked promising. He was bringing a Group A twin-cam Suzuki Cultus (Chevrolet Sprint in the U.S.), a real buzz bomb at just a tick over 1,800 pounds and bursting with a powerful 130-horse, sixteen-valve 1,299cc four-cylinder engine. It’s only competition in the under-1,300cc class would be from three tricked-out Toyota Starlets. Kenzo Sudo would be co-driving with Kenyu Azechi in a second Cultus—a backup parts car for Tajima’s effort. If Kenzo wasn’t worried by the language barrier, I wasn’t going to worry about it, either. I figured I could yell "Yakitori!" for the log piles (beef on a skewer, if you catch my drift), and for anything else that could kill us, I would smack Tajima on the helmet and yell "No!" real loud. So I signed on.

With only five days remaining until the start of Olympus, we would have no time to make our own notes of the four-day, 850-mile rally’s forty speed stages. But we didn’t worry. Rod Millen (second in the 1986 PRO Rally Championship) and his Canadian co-driver, John Bellefleur, had prepared a set of simple numbered notes, using one through seven to describe the turns (seven being the fastest), and generously let us copy the entire 102-page handwritten document. This is what a typical line looked like: R7 + LgL5 < + L5 15

I would read, "Right seven and, long left five opens and, left five fifteen." Tajima would expect an almost flat-out right bend, followed quickly by a long, tight left-hander that opened up and led into another tight left and a 150-meter straight.
"Kampeki!" said Tajima, when we showed him. Perfect. We all beamed, and turned toward the forest to practice Day One of the four-day event.

Tajima and I rode in the front seat of the rented Ford Escort, while Kenzo and Azechi-san sat in the rear with their own copy of the pace notes. Kenzo alternated between reading the notes aloud to Azechi in Japanese and translating between Tajima and me. Rainstorms had battered Washington for weeks, and the forest roads were in pretty rough shape. One stage had already been canceled where part of the road gave way to a fifty-foot crater. As we wound our way through the mountains in the rent-a-car, trying to project how fast the Cultus would handle the slimy gravel and thick mud, Tajima would adjust the notes. "Jean-san, no left five. Left four," he would say in halting English.
"Kampeki," I said. "Perfect." The three of them thought my Japanese was hysterically funny.

We were in general a pretty good-natured bunch. Tajima kept the two in the back seat in stitches all day. And now and then, he would burst into song—apparently the only one he knew in English: "Everybody loves somebody sometime…" he would croon.
"Tsuki ga deta deta," I would wail in reply. They went bananas. The only song I knew in Japanese was a famous drinking song.

That night we set up the rally car on a little two-mile stretch of dirt road, working with the brake bias and suspension settings, aiming the rack of driving lamps, and checking out the intercom. I had never rallied in a front-wheel-drive car and was surprised at the amount of sawing at the wheel Tajima had to do to place the Cultus where he wanted it in the turns. It was especially noticeable because we were sitting literally side by side, with arms nearly touching, in the tiny right-hand-drive car. I had to jam my right shoulder and arm inside the wing of the seat to keep from being pounded by Tajima’s flailing elbows as he ripped through turns. My leg would have taken a similar beating during shifting if it hadn’t been for two special foam-padded aluminum uprights, one to hold his left leg in, one to keep my right leg away from the shift lever.

The Cultus was surprisingly fast, with a serious case of torque coming on strong right at the bottom of the rev range. We ran silently up and down our two-mile test track, painfully aware of the absence of our translator. When we climbed out, Tajima spoke to Kenzo.
"He wants to know what you think of the rally car," Kenzo translated.
"Well, it’s kinda slow, isn’t it?" I said with a straight face. Kenzo looked shocked, but laid it on Tajima in Japanese. Tajima looked at me and broke into a big grin. We would do okay together.

Practice seemed to be going well; Tajima would drive as fast as the sorry little rental Escort could handle the rough forest tracks, while I called out the turns and speed, always one turn ahead of where we were. Tajima would add cautions for drop-offs and narrow wooden plank bridges ("No left four, Jean-san; left four caution"), raise the rated speed for some turns, lower it for the others, and generally customize Millen and Bellefleur’s notes to his needs.

We stopped by the side of the road in the little town of Porter to eat the lunch Azechi brought along: rice balls stuffed with a salted plum and wrapped in nori, pickled daikon, and green tea. When I dug into my rice ball with gusto, Tajima looked at me and announced, "You're Japanese."
"Beer-u kudasai," I replied. I want beer.
That little exchange must have been the impetus Tajima needed to admit, after having practiced two days of the four-day rally, that he couldn’t hear the difference between left and right.

"Jean-san, you know it is hard for Japanese people to say 'l' and 'r,'" began Kenzo. "It is also very difficult to hear the difference. And both words are very short and end with 't.' Tajima hopes that you can use Japanese."
I’m going to die.

Left became hidari, and right became migi. We practiced the last stage of the day, with me looking at "L7 + R4" in the notes and reading aloud "Hidari seven and migi four." It sounded loony to all of us, especially when I added "sugu" (very soon) and changed all turns numbered 1, 2, and 3 to "hairpin." So I’d holler something like, "Hidari four onto bridge, sugu migi five over crest, and hidari hairpin."
Tajima said he understood it. I said, okay, bubba-san.

pageElements.text: Thursday evening at 8:20, we sat in darkness in our Cultus on the main floor of the Tacoma Dome, as the spotlight played on each team rolling up the starting ramp for this momentous race. Juha Kankkunen and Markku Alen, the two fiercest competitors in rallying, were battling for the championship in two off the most exotic rally cars ever built—the 450-horsepower, four-wheel-drive Peugeot 205 Turbo 16, and the supercharged and turbocharged 480-horsepower, four-wheel-drive Lancia Delta S4. Had it been run in Europe, this rally would have drawn literally millions of spectators. (Over three million people watched the Lombard RAC rally in England each of the past two years.) I looked around the darkened arena. It was virtually empty.
"Yesterday, Billy Joel,” I joked. “Today, Tajima."
"Yesterday, many people,” came Tajima’s reply. “Today, no people."

We got off to a tentative start: it would be out first reading of the pace notes at speed, and with no translator in the car. Not taking any chances, I had written out every single Japanese word above the coded English notes for stage one and stage two, so there would be no slipups. The first stage, a paved section of an abandoned housing development in Tacoma, was icy, and we slid wide into the bushes once but got straightened out. We finished three seconds behind our teammate Azechi in class. More important, we realized that this was actually going to work.

The rally moved forty-six miles west to the private Weyerhaeuser forest, and we dove into the woods, picking up the pace as our confidence in each other grew. The second stage went much better, and we emerged from the forest to find our all-Japanese service crew glowing like a neon sign in the night in their screaming yellow jumpsuits, bright red baseball caps, and forehead-mounted lanterns. They threw some gas in the tank and offered me a banana and a gallon jug of water. (I had told them I would eat whatever they had planned for Tajima, but I had asked if they could also have water and maybe bananas in the van.) We drove on.

Tajima only went faster, eventually finishing the night’s racing in twelfth position overall, and first in Group A’s under-1,300cc class, a full two minutes ahead of the second-place Azechi. Amazingly, Tajima had leap-frogged the Cultus over more than a dozen bigger Group A cars. We ran the brilliant Suzuki through a car wash, changed the front tires, clocked into headquarters at 3:11 in the morning, and set our alarms for the 10:00 a.m. restart. This is how the second day went:

Stage 7

It’s pouring rain as we head into the Capitol Forest. This stage is almost seventeen miles long and very tricky—full of tight right-handers and a few hairpins. We feel good coming out of it fifteenth overall. At service, crew chief Tamura runs by my window, pulls himself up short, mimes a drink, and rushes back to me with the ubiquitous banana and gallon of water. I peek in the van and find four bunches of bananas, and a crate of gallon water jugs. It’s what I asked for, after all.

Stage 8

Tajima has one foot on the gas, the other on the brake, and is drifting the Cultus hard through a long left sweeper, when we are suddenly and violently thrown into the ditch. Thank God we are thrown to the inside ditch, instead of over the cliff. The left front tire is flat, and Tajima yells at me in Japanese.
"What? What?!" I yell through my helmet. Tajima pulls me to the rear of the rally car and pantomimes that I should push while he drives. I think I remember this part.

We force the Cultus back onto the road and change the tire in under three minutes. But there is a sickening gnashing and gnarling in the rear as we try to pull away. We leap out again and find there is no right rear tire. There is no right rear wheel. The brake drum has shattered at the hub, and the only thing left is a set of junked brake shoes dangling from a spindle. Blecchh.

Tajima is yelling at me in Japanese as we jump back into the Cultus. What is he saying?! He reaches past me to open my door, pushing me and firing up the engine at the same time. It takes a minute, but I finally catch on: I’m to hang out of the car on the left like the monkey on a sidecar, to keep the right rear spindle off the ground. We’re going to finish this stage if it kills us. Or me.

Three miles and a lifetime later, we slide past the finish line, but with no rear brakes, we continue downhill another 200 meters before Tajima can stop. I run uphill, record our score, and fly back to the wounded Cultus. My legs feel just like they feel in my worst nightmares. Adrenaline is leaking out of my ears. I jump aboard, grab the roll cage, and throw myself back out the left door. Our service crew is a mile down the highway.

This is serious. We should have been leaving service at the time we limp in. We have only a certain number of minutes before we must show up for the next stage, or we’ll be time-barred from the rally. Every way I figure it, we’re in big trouble. Tamura has an entire rear axle assembly in the van, and the crew is stripping it of the parts we need to continue. The next stage is six miles away. We have nineteen minutes to get there. Can you say "time-barred" in Japanese?
"No time!" I shout at Tajima. He is working desperately with the crew, in full-face helmet, intercom cord dangling, trying to put the right rear together. "No brakes!" he yells back.
How can I tell him? It is 12:10. I write "12:24 DNF," underline it in angry black, and show it to him. "Hai," he says.
But does he really understand? I have no other way of communicating. Every other minute I yell, "No time! No time! DNF!"

Mercifully, he finally climbs back into the car, helmet on, and we are racing to the next stage. But it’s no use. We clock in five minutes past our deadline. There is always the outside chance that a stage will be discounted and we won't be time-barred, but I’m devastated. In the morning, the officials will surely throw us out of the rally.

pages.name: page3

pageElements.text:
Stage 9

"Jean-san," Tajima calls me on the intercom as we creep through the turns at a snail’s pace. "Strut-u broke-u. Shock-u broke-u." We are thirty-seventh fastest of forty-two cars. (How can we have beaten anyone with the front end in a shambles?) The crew is waiting at the end of the twelve-mile stage. There is barely time—ten minutes or so—to strip away the junk struts and shock and send us on our way.

Stage 10

The lightning-quick strut change has left us with an impossible amount of negative camber on the left front wheel, not a good situation in a front-drive car. We are twenty-eighth fastest. We have another eye-blink service during which Tamura does a lick-and-a-promise alignment.

Stage 11

We are sixteenth fastest in the stage, sixteen seconds faster than Azechi. There’s a problem, though, and Tajima has the crew try another roadside alignment.

Stage 12

We’re now twelfth fastest. Tajima is back on the pace, a minute and ten seconds faster than our competition. His smile is brilliant when he pulls off his helmet. I’m thinking about being disqualified in the morning.

Stage 13

We are twelfth fastest again. Fighting a car that doesn’t want to turn right, Tajima manages to pass two backmarkers.

Stage 14

Tajima is a man possessed, and posts the eleventh fastest time of the stage. We’ve moved up thirteen places.

We have a major service break, and Tamura orders new tires and takes a serious look at the suspension. The crew continues to work on the alignment. As we head down the highway, I try to cheer Tajima. "Very fast," I grin.
He does not grin. "Jean-san, steering-u no good," he says. He takes his hands from the wheel. The Cultus leaps for the left ditch, and he jerks it back on course.
"Steering-u no good. Caution," Tajima says again.
“Hai,” I say, eyes big.

Stage 15

Tajima soaks his gloves in the ditch before the stage starts, to get a grip on the bucking wheel. Right turns take a herculean effort, and masterful hand- and footwork. It’s getting harder, though, and we finish seventeenth fastest. The body structure is obviously bent.

Stage 16

We are seventeenth fastest again.

Stage 17

The handling is absolutely diabolical, but this is the last stage of the night. For us, it’s our last stage, period. The seven-mile stage begins with a flurry of superfast rights and lefts. About two miles in, I call a fast right turn leading to an almost ninety-degree right onto a cement bridge. I look down at my notes to see what is coming next, as Tajima slows for the bridge. And then he roars. It is the noise they teach you to make in karate class right before you kick in the rapist’s sternum.
"Aaarrggh!" wails Tajima.

I bolt upright and see the cement bridge looming in the windshield of our sliding Cultus. On my side. Tajima forces the understeering Cultus wide of the bridge, and almost comes to a stop at the side of the bank. Almost.

As we tumble off the edge of the world, I think, "How far down is the water, and how deep is it going to be?" About ten feet and two feet are the immediate answers, and we park the Cultus on its nose, engine running, in Fall Creek. It is quiet but for the sound of the stream burbling through our engine compartment.
"Jean-san," says Tajima. "Rally finish."
"Hai," I say.

We crawl hand over hand up the embankment and wait for the wrecker. In eighteen years of racing, this is Tajima’s first crash. "Nobu-chan," I call him by his nickname, and tug his sleeve as he leans forlornly against the bridge. "Better crash than time-bar." It sounds honorable to me.

There was nothing left but to follow the rally for the final two days and cheer on Kenzo and Azechi to their eventual class victory. Tajima joined the service team, and I walked into the woods to see the battle for the championship. I had never seen the European supercars race, and I shared the naked thrill of one seventeen-year-old when first Alen’s Lancia, then Kankkunen’s Peugeot burst into the clearing with a shriek, waste gates hissing like vipers on the downshift. Stones battered the crowd as the mad machines stormed through a hairpin, and turbochargers glowed red as the Finns shot away.
"This is serious shit, man!" said the stunned kid, his eyes fairly bugging out of his head.
Right about that, kid. I had a nightmare last night, one that included a cement bridge and rubber legs. I’m glad I’m not crazy.

metaDescription: Wit and Wisdom of the Moss-Carlssons: a classic book, sadly out of print. Here are some snippets, on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Pat Moss and Erik Carlsson were rallying royalty. Pat, whose story we’ve told in our Notorious Women series, was the younger sister of Stirling Moss (more about him here and here). She was a ladies’ champion in rallying, and she married Erik Carlsson, a rally driver for Saab who was one of the first inducted into the Rally Hall of Fame. What better couple to write a book on driving technique? Which they did.

Their classic book The Art and Technique of Driving, published in 1965, is unfortunately out of print. There are definitely parts that are quaint (“There is no proof that car radios cause accidents….if you do decide to have one, it must be fitted properly by an expert”), but so much in this book is solid, wise advice that somebody really ought to get this back into print. Because really, wouldn’t you love to have these two sitting in the car with you, giving you advice about techniques they honed in the Alps?
Here are some of our favorite parts.

On Being a Good (or Bad) Driver

“Although we can assume that nearly all slow drivers are bad, we cannot assume that nearly all bad drivers are slow.”

“One of the best tests of a good driver is passenger reaction. A normal passenger who is able to drive should stop reaching for his footbrake after five minutes. Your driving should make him feel relaxed and safe by that time.”
“The simple and obvious truth about cornering is that good drivers do it safely and bad drivers do not.”

“Both of us are bad passengers and seem to suffer unduly from bad drivers. A lot of people start showing off as soon as they know you are a competition driver. They want to prove that they could have been world champions if they had been given the chance, so they go wild and take terrible risks…One of the worst examples was in America when a taxi-driver recognized us and started driving like mad over a wet, slippery road. Suddenly the car went broadside and for some strange reason both the rear doors flew open. We cowered in the back clutching at the seats and at each other to keep from falling out as the taxi went sideways down the street. The driver had his own way of dealing with the situation. He put all the blame on the cab and shouted at it: ‘Now then, Rosemary! That’s no way to behave.’ ”

On Being Physically Comfortable in the Car

“You should try to be physically relaxed while driving, and it is quite possible to do this while remaining mentally alert…We both have some experience of racing as well as rallying, and we can assure you that a racing driver who was physically tense and who clutched at the wheel would not have the sensitivity to drive the car fast round corners. The heart of a surgeon during a difficult operation probably beats as fast as the heart of a racing driver during a difficult race, but no one has ever suggested that a surgeon should hold his scalpel in the tight, feelingless grip of a boy whittling a stick. Good surgery and good driving both need a light sensitive touch.”

On Reading the Road

"Anticipation is one of the most valuable assets for good driving. The classic example was something which happened during the Monaco Grand Prix race in 1950. This race is run through the streets of Monte Carlo, and it was won that year by [Juan Manuel] Fangio, one of the best racing drivers of all time…He was roaring around the circuit in his Alfa Romeo and as he approached a tricky corner he suddenly noticed that there was something different about the crowd. It did not look the same as usual. There was not the normal whitish blur of faces.

“Fangio braked hard. He realized that if the faces were not white, then the people in the crowd were not looking towards him. They were looking away from him at something more interesting. Fangio went round the corner more slowly than usual—and around it there was a tremendous pileup of racing cars. If he had been going at normal speed he would have crashed into them…The effect of good observation and interpretation in normal road driving can be just as dramatic and as important to the driver.”

“Observation comes first and interpretation follows...A driver traveling at 30 mph in town is able to notice events and movements in his immediate vicinity because his eyes are adjusted for what might be called close work. At 70 or 80 mph, a driver’s eyes are focused to observe things 200 or 300 or even 400 yards away. He is slow to notice things happening just a few feet from his car…The driver who thinks correctly will be able to appreciate the various and sometimes obscure possibilities of any particular traffic situation and to interpret his observations.”

On Dealing with Other Drivers

“Some people seem to regard it as their duty to ensure that no other motorist exceeds the speed limit. Some other people are genuinely worried about whether they can be charged with aiding and abetting a crime if they allow someone to overtake at 50 mph in a 40-mph zone.

“Our advice to all these people is: If someone exceeding the speed limit wants to go past, then pull over and let him through. A driver who is unable to obey the law and keep within the speed limit may also be bumptious, overbearing, bad-tempered, and an appalling driver. So you should do everything in your power to see that there is as big a distance as possible between his car and yours.”

On Rallying

“Fog is probably the motorist’s worst enemy. Everybody hates it, including the authors. Nevertheless we have been quoted in newspapers once or twice as saying that we wanted fog on a particular rally. We admit that we did say so. We do like fog on rallies. The reason is that all cars are reduced to roughly the same speed…Our Saab cars have quite small engines, so fog on a rally is an advantage to us...”

“There is really only one piece of advice that we can give to anyone who is preparing to try some competition driving. It is: Speed matters, and the longer your foot is on the brake the less it is on the accelerator.”
