metaTitle: 2013 Porsche Cayenne in Carmine Red - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Porsche Cayenne in Carmine Red is a particular favorite of senior editor Molly Jean's. She'll tell you more than you want to know about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The best thing about Michigan winters is the sensation of slipping into flannel sheets at the end of the day. If you have never slept in a cold house with flannel sheets, or if you are a flannel hater, read no further. I have a shopping tip to share with flannel lovers. It is a bit pricey, but my hands say it is worth every penny.

The 2013 Porsche Cayenne GTS steering wheel is wrapped in Alcantara—a fabulous composite material that has the look and feel of suede but apparently has better durability. I would have never imagined that the feel of a steering wheel would be the biggest impression left after driving a $137,000 vehicle.

When I first caught sight of this vermilion beauty in the parking lot, I was taken by its shade of red. I have never been a fan of red cars. When I think of red cars, visions of mid-1980s Pontiacs pop into my mind. But this Cayenne’s red is sublime. Think red barns, juicy red apples, sweet raspberries. The official name is Carmine Red, which comes with an upcharge of $3,140. But with a base price of $83,025, who's counting pennies?

A Great Hour

The dash is also wrapped in luscious Alcantara. But it gets better: it has red stitching and red seatbelts, all details courtesy of two interior packages at an additional $7,105. I was only in the Cayenne for an hour, but I must say it was a great hour. This is the first SUV that I have driven that felt like a sports car. It was a bit scary to think that in some parts of the country, I could buy a house for the price of this vehicle. But the whole time I was driving, I was distracted by the Alcantara. As I drove, I kept moving my hands around on the steering wheel because it felt so damn good.
Mother’s Day is right around the corner, and nothing says love like a juicy-red, flannel-lined Porsche Cayenne.

title: Ford's Good-Food Finder App
subTitle: Know where to get a smoothie in Salinas?
promoTeaserSmall: Find good, healthy, even vegan eating places all over the U.S. with a free smartphone/iPad app.
promoTeaser: Find good, healthy, even vegan eating places all over the U.S. with a free smartphone/iPad app.
metaTitle: Ford's Good-Food Finder App - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Ford's Good-Food Finder App, Food Tripping, can help smartphone and iPad users find good places to eat healthy food all over the U.S. The story is on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When Ford and SHFT.com previewed their new app, Food Tripping, for Earth Day 2013, the dinner party was held at The Leadbelly in New York City. The seasonal spread included a wide selection of East Coast oysters, a farm-to-table family-style meal, and biodynamic wines. The small establishment, tucked into the narrow side streets of lower Manhattan, is one of those cool neighborhood spots that you’d never find except by word of mouth or an app.

And that’s just what Food Tripping is all about. The app, available for use on iPhones, iPads, and Android phones, allows users to find a range of fresh, local, seasonal, and healthy food options on the go. The free app has a database of over 100,000 “good food” restaurants, farmers’ markets, juice bars, organic grocery stores, and more across the United States.

Sustainability Stars Are Behind the App

Film producer Peter Glatzer and actor/filmmaker Adrian Grenier founded SHFT.com in December 2009. “Our mission is to nudge sustainable ideas and designs into pop culture, and to provide context for an inspiring and sustainable way of life,” explained Glatzer.

Inspiring, yes. The site, which has won two Webby awards, is a colorful conglomerate of clever content that covers everything from art and architecture to fashion and food. The filmmakers have incorporated a mix of well-produced videos and The Big SHFT, an original series about innovators in sustainability, produced in partnership with Ford.

“Sustainability is the biggest issue facing business in the twenty-first century, and the problem will not be solved by one person or group,” said Ford Motor Company executive chairman Bill Ford. "How we answer the challenge of the future of mobility will have a lasting impact on generations to come. By partnering with organizations like SHFT, we are able to inspire people to make smart decisions about the products they choose today.”
In fact, Bill Ford believed in SHFT so much that he joined its board, joining other great minds that include Richard Branson and Arianna Huffington.

“Ford is a huge game changer for us,” said Glatzer. “This is just one example of how Ford has put their money and their commitment to bringing options to people who are looking for alternatives to the norm. Ford has a phrase, ‘the power of choice,’ and SHFT is about showing people options.”

What Can You Find with It?

The Food Tripping app, Glatzer said, "is about focusing on all of the smaller hidden gems around the country…anything from vegan markets to organic wineries, cheese makers, dairies, or microbrewers.”

Grenier, who lives in New York City, added: “Food is one of the best gateways to a bigger lifestyle change. We are all about showcasing things in a way that is inspiring and titillating." To create a broader base of inspiring food options, Food Tripping is looking to users to populate the app with their own favorite food places around the country.

“SHFT has been 100 million percent rewarding. I feel that I am doing something that matters,” says the well-known actor, who starred on HBO’s Entourage. “I can act and create entertainment and prance around like a movie star, but what’s the takeaway? This kind of work is extremely satisfying [to the] body, mind and soul.”
Glatzer commented: “We don’t want to be activists, elitist or crunchy.  We just want to live better. We are just guys that created a platform that anyone can access.”

How It Works

Food Tripping, available for free for iPhone, iPad, and Android, is a fun format that's super easy to use. First, open the app and click on your current location. Next, browse through a list of healthy categories: eateries, farmers’ markets, food markets, coffee and tea, juice joints and smoothies, vegan and vegetarian, drink artisans, and food artisans.

After selecting your choices, the app will present you with a well-designed map and list of places with addresses and phone numbers. There are also buttons for suggestions, favorite places, and names of businesses if you want to get more specific. I looked up the name "Jean" and came up with sustainable eateries located in Florida and Missouri. Then, just for the heck of it, I looked up "McDonald’s." No results!

How Can You Get It?

Food Tripping will be available late 2013 in the Ford Sync system, but until then, you can download it from the SHFT website.

images.caption: SHFT.com and Ford combined forces to create the Food Tripping app.
You're used to navigation by now; this navigates you to a healthy meal.
App has search function and can save your favorites.
One less excuse to keep you from eating well wherever you are.

title: Range Rover Evoque: Road Trip!
subTitle: To New York Auto Show with room for 3
promoTeaserSmall: To New York Auto Show with room for 3
promoTeaser: Attractive, sure-footed as a mountain goat, and able to carry extra hat boxes acquired in Manhattan.
metaTitle: Range Rover Evoque: Road Trip! - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Range Rover Evoque: Road Trip to New York City for the auto show. Watch the video and read my story about my Evoque road trip history. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I love road trips. My husband, Tim, and I prefer to drive whenever we’re going on a trip if we have the time. He especially likes to drive, so I frequently find myself in the role of passenger for hours on end. In the case of this road trip, from Michigan to New York City for the New York Auto Show, we brought along videographer Scott Allen.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/qVmw-1BbJeY?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The only problem: there were three of us and all our stuff. Tim had to drive the entire distance, because he couldn’t fit in either the front passenger's seat or the back seat. I literally sat upright in the passenger's seat; I couldn’t put the seat back, because Scott was sitting right behind me. On the bright side, there was no problem with seatroom in the back, no problem with headroom, and the panoramic window helped prevent claustrophobia.

My Evoque History

This wasn't our first trip in the Evoque. Last New Year’s Eve, Tim and I decided on a whim to drive from Michigan to visit a dear friend in New Hampshire whom we were missing. It was really cold but not snowing badly. However, we knew we were heading into a blizzard.

At Automobile Magazine, we had had a history of breakdown problems with Land Rover products in the past. Consumer Reports rates the Evoque at fifty-eight out of 100 points overall, dead last in its category of compact sporty SUVs. We wondered, would it be okay to take this car across the country in a blizzard?

We decided that we were going to go for it anyway, and we sure did hit a blizzard. Driving through it, the Evoque was a tank. It was a mountain goat. It was as solid as a rock. You get the idea: it never slipped, and it was steady. Loved the 240-horsepower turbocharged engine, too. On the way home, it was seriously windy and cold, but the wind didn't buffet the car at all. In fact, the wind was unnoticeable while we were moving.
We're really glad that the Evoque was the vehicle we took to New Hampshire, and equally glad to have chosen it to take us to New York City this time.

But Can It Carry Enough Hats?

The short answer: yes. On this trip to the auto show, I planned to visit a couple of hatmakers (see videos of my shopping adventures with New York hatmakers Barbara Feinman and Jasmin Zorlu), so I was doubly worried about space. In the end, as you'll see in the video, I shifted a few bags and jammed a couple more hat boxes in there. It worked out great.

metaDescription: 2014 Kia Soul made its debut at the New York Auto Show, where chief designer Tom Kearns walked me around it. See the video on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Maybe the first thing you think of when you think about the Kia Soul is hamsters. That would make sense, because that famous series of  hamster commercials helped make the Soul a hit as an "urban passenger vehicle." The all-new 2014 Soul made its debut at the New York Auto Show, and design chief Tom Kearns walked me around it and showed what's new about it.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/uZqPH3HCwYo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

As he says in the video, design cues from the 2012 Track'ster concept (shown at right) were important in the new design, such as the floating body-color liftgate insert on the back end, which Kearns calls a "backpack" look. The 2014 Soul is just about as boxy as ever on the outside, wrapped around an all-new chassis that Kia says is 29 percent stiffer for better ride and handling.

It's on the inside that the changes are most evident, with soft-touch materials and an overall feeling of quality improvement. You can even get leather seating and an eight-inch touchscreen. If you move up to the top-level Soul Exclaim, options will include a piano black center console, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a cooled glove box (!). Hamsters in evening clothes?
The 2014 Soul is expected out in early fall.

title: Fiat Goes Electric with the 500e
subTitle: Sorry, it's for California only
promoTeaserSmall: Sorry, it's for California only
promoTeaser: The all-electric Fiat comes for a visit, and we are charmed.
metaTitle: Fiat Goes Electric with the 500e - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Fiat Goes Electric with the 500e, a California-only electric version of the popular, stylish Fiat 500. It came to Michigan for a visit, and we were charmed. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Some of us at Jean Knows Cars have it bad for the Fiat 500. It’s cute, it’s affordable, it’s foreign; what’s not to like?

Not much, and starting this summer, when the larger and more practical 500L and the fully electric 500e go on sale, even less. Those models are still a few months away from their on-sale dates, but being the sister website to Automobile Magazine (and sharing a parking lot) has its benefits. This week, one of those benefits is that there’s a 500e hooked up to the charging station.

When Fiat’s team dropped off the 500e last week, they told us about the car’s impressive 108 MPGe on the highway and its 87 miles of combined city/highway driving range, but what they really wanted to talk about was what made the 500e different from its EV brethren.

Not Your Standard Electric Car

For starters, you can search all you want, but you won’t find an “eco” button on the dash. There also aren’t animated leaves or growing forests to tell you whether you’re driving efficiently. Fiat designed this car to feel and drive as much like a gasoline-powered car as possible—except that it has the instant torque that makes electric motors so much fun. That philosophy may not resonate with some ultra-environmentally-conscious electric-car buyers, but I can’t help liking a car that bucks its paradigm so willfully.

Some Heavy Numbers

Of course, some concessions must be made to electrical power. The 500e is 617 pounds heavier than the base Fiat 500, and some rear legroom has been sacrificed to accommodate the battery. The 500e's electronically limited top speed of 85 mph won’t exactly set any records, either.

The car will come with a standard navigation system, which will help drivers find their way to the nearest charging station, and a free mobile app that will allow drivers to monitor their car’s state of charge, search for the nearest charge point, and plan trips. Fiat is also giving drivers twelve days' worth of free car rentals for each of their first three years of ownership, in case they need a car that will make a longer trip or need to move a couch across town.

The 500e will start at $32,500 (including destination) when it goes on sale in California this summer. Buyers in other markets will have to look on with jealousy until Fiat decides to expand availability for its electric car.

title: Kid-Friendly Vacation Trip Planning
subTitle: Five ways to get them involved
promoTeaserSmall: Yes, you can take a road trip that's fun for the kids without plugging them in to video screens.
promoTeaser: Yes, you can take a road trip that's fun for the kids without plugging them in to video screens.
metaTitle: Kid-Friendly Vacation Trip Planning - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: how to take children on a vacation
metaDescription: Kid-Friendly Vacation Trip Planning will help your family have a more united and memorable time in the car. Here are five ways to get your children involved in preparing to go out on the road. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Going on a road trip with children rarely turns out the way you fantasize. So it's pretty similar to the rest of your life with children. Go ahead and plan, organize, and expect all you want; things will have to adjust. It's all a matter of having the right attitude toward the inevitable twists and turns. For that reason, a driving trip can be the best way to take kids on an adventure, because you are literally at the wheel and can stop the car or change the itinerary in ways you can't on an airplane, a train, or a cruise ship.

As a veteran of many adventure drives with kids of all ages (see my Road Trips with Teens story), I have come up with this handy list of five ways you can involve your children in planning for a road trip.

1. Let Them Fantasize

Do you remember having huge travel dreams as a kid, which your parents responded to by cutting them down to size? I remember my sister and I wanting to take a bicycle trip across the United States as preteens, with no more plans than the dream of pedaling endless sunny, traffic-free, flat asphalt lanes all day and sleeping in wildflower meadows at night. My parents wouldn't let us get to Square One. I think they actually laughed. You may say, "Of course they did! That was a ridiculously clueless idea."

If my kids expressed that bicycle fantasy to me, I would help them plot out a family car trip that included a night or two of rustic camping and a one-day family biking event in some town a state or two away. That might be enough to satisfy their bike-trip dreams forever. But it could also start them on the path toward a lifetime membership in a bicycle touring society. How about finding out what your kids' dream of a road trip looks like? Then take that and make the adjustments you have to, while helping them fulfill just enough of it to keep the flame alive. Sometimes just taking children seriously is enough to make you a great parent.

2. Give Them Map Power

Yes, you've got a fancy navigation system these days, plus Siri, plus Google Maps. Get an atlas or a paper map anyway that kids can write on with a highlighter, crumple up, and learn to fold. Any elementary school teacher will tell you that a tactile experience helps kids learn. Take off for a short day trip carrying a state, county, or city map. Picture how great it will look with your kid's carefully drawn route from home to the amusement park or the lake, and your kid using it to see how close to "Are we there yet?" you are. You can back it up with Google Maps, or put your kid on the computer and let him or her Google Map it for you. Then, let your kids take turns as navigator, sitting in the front passenger's seat if they're over twelve and tall enough, and using their maps to direct you. Okay, it's good to teach them how to use the car's navigation system, too. The point is to put your kids at the center of the navigation experience.

3. Turn Them into Trip Trackers

Some families like to keep a travel diary. If you want to try that, put your kids in charge of writing things down like departure times, starting and ending mileage, and impressions of different places you stop. Give them a box to collect receipts, postcards, and brochures. Help them notice things like gasoline prices, figure out how many exits are left until you get to the next hotel, and suggest possible stopping points along the way. Keep kids actively involved in the process of getting where you are going. Don't turn them into passive occupants of the back seat with no personal stake in how the day goes.

4. Make Them Governor of a State (or Mayor of a City)

Don't be obnoxious about it and assign kids to write reports, but do put them in charge of finding out about the places you're going. If you are crossing multiple states, put each child in charge of a state and make him or her the point person for information. What famous people come from there? (Not just presidents, but rock stars and TV actors they actually care about.) What geographical features shouldn't you miss when you're driving through? The whole time you are in that state, that kid is the go-to family member. Encourage them to notice if there's a town with an amusing or interesting name, or a sign for the Millard Fillmore Museum or the World's Largest Artichoke. Then pull off the highway and go look at the town for fifteen minutes. Help your kids figure out what a "not to be missed" experience consists of. The Disney Worlds and Grand Canyons are essential, of course, but don't be in such a hurry that you miss out on the small happenings that will turn into family jokes and shared history. There are things to learn everywhere, even if it's just the visual stimulus that comes from people watching.

5. Give Kids Control of What the Family Hears and Watches...Up to a Point

If you've read this far, you must agree with me that a road trip with kids is not a necessary evil to get through, but an adventure to be embraced. If so, you'll want to avoid the temptation to plug your kids in to an endless cycle of videos, video games, and iPod music with headphones. I'm not saying you won't ever want to resort to that; technology allows each of us to have "alone time" while sitting right next to each other. That's exactly why you want to limit it. Why put everybody in the car as a family and then ignore each other? Instead, bite the bullet and let your kids have control of what the group listens to for some of the time, and listen to it together. Some of my favorite drives are when my teenage son Henry acts as DJ and plays me everything from vintage Bob Dylan to weird Japanese electronic music. I get some sense of what's going on inside his head.

Take everybody to the library for audiobooks (or get a free OverDrive account and borrow audiobooks from the library to download onto your iPhone, iPad, or iPod). Listen to short stories or podcasts that somehow relate to the place you're visiting. Get one of the kids to make a playlist of music that suits the trip. Even toddlers can learn to prefer stories read aloud in the car. That's so much better than a constant stream of cartoon videos that block out the scenery they should be looking at on a trip. Having said that, you don't have to be shackled to tween pop music stations the whole time, and you do get to put on NPR or whatever you'd rather be listening to. Sharing your favorite things, and then being patient while others share theirs, is a lesson the whole family can keep on learning.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: For Corry Weller, driving a truck in the Lucas Oil Off Road Racing Series means soaring over jumps, slamming to the ground, and sliding sideways through 180-degree turns. Because off-road trucks don’t have windshields, she gets splattered with mud. The truck is a twitchy beast and will roll over easily if she doesn’t use the greatest care and precision.

In her second season as the only woman behind the wheel of a Pro 4 Unlimited entry, which is the top class in the Lucas Oil series, Weller has distinguished herself. The forty-one-year-old Chandler, Arizona, resident was 2012 Rookie of the Year, with a best finish of second place. Her goal is to win a race this season, and next year, she wants to contend for the series championship.

I met Weller last Friday at Lake Elsinore Motorsports Park in southern California before the fifth and sixth rounds of the series. From a starting field of eleven trucks, she finished fourth in both Saturday’s and Sunday’s races, averaging 79 mph per lap on the rutted, twisting 1.1-mile course.

After her first practice session, she was relaxing in her Optima Batteries/Tilted Kilt team hospitality area. She explained how she started in motocross twelve years ago. “I was in a bad marriage and needed to get away and do something to de-stress, just for one-half of a day,” she said. Supercross races on TV fascinated her, and she found herself visiting a powersports dealer. She purchased a four-wheeler, or quad, for the track.

Role Model for the Kids

For technical support, she had her father. “My dad was a car guy,” she said. “I grew up in the garage with him.” She had also taken automotive courses in high school and college and knew how to handle tools. Having now discovered her passion, she was on her way to five years of motocross success. Her six-year-old daughter and four-year-old son saw their mommy getting all fired up and winning races.
“I never really knew what I wanted to do,” she said. “I just went where life took me until I started racing. As soon as I started racing, I was like, ‘That’s what I have to do.’ ”

After motocrossing on the quad, the intermediate step was short-course racing on a Yamaha Rhino, a larger all-terrain vehicle with a 700-cc two-cylinder engine and four-wheel drive. Meanwhile, she married her second husband, Jason Weller. To have a job with a flexible schedule, she went to work at a Tilted Kilt pub. Her manager backed her with measured support, and then the chain’s leaders decided to sponsor her move up to the Pro 4 Unlimited division. Optima Batteries joined the effort this year.

image.altText: corry weller off road truck racer

pageElements.text:
Intensity behind the Wheel

Weller’s impressive performances come from her ability to tune out the pandemonium and finesse this heavy, roaring, V-8-powered, four-wheel-drive truck. A highly technical and disciplined driving style is required.

“I don’t really think about what I’m going to do on the face of jumps any more because I’m so used to what my truck does,” she said. “That’s all just reflex and now I can focus 100 percent on the race, what’s going on, because my subconscious is doing all the little stuff.”

Each of the weekend’s Lake Elsinore races covered sixteen laps, which meant an intense physical ordeal lasting just over twenty minutes. Weller prepares with a daily CrossFit workout supplemented by additional weightlifting. “I also eat pretty clean and drink tons of water,” she said. “Fitness plays a huge part in your reaction times on the track and helps with these brutal races and throwing the truck around.”

Strange Bedfellow

While every racer finds his or her own rewards, for Weller the ultimate satisfaction comes from taking on a new challenge, like moving up to Pro 4 and steadily improving. While she admitted that she once slept with a first-place trophy, she said winning is more for the people who tirelessly support her. “Otherwise, me, myself, I’m just happy racing, honestly.”

title: 11 Plant Tours You'll Actually Like
subTitle: These are not just for kids
promoTeaserSmall: See where your car was made. View Harleys or Airstreams in progress. Part of your complete vacation!
promoTeaser: See where your car was made. View Harleys or Airstreams in progress. Part of your complete vacation!
metaTitle: 11 Plant Tours You'll Actually Like - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 11 Plant Tours You'll Actually Like is our list of vehicle manufacturers across the heart of the United States that invite you to take a tour of their production sites this summer. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Trying to think of fun yet stimulating things to do this summer? Suppose you took the kids on an educational tour where they could see cars being built, and maybe even the same kind that you own. Drive your Camry to the Camry plant, or your Ford truck to the Ford truck plant. With the high level of robotics in today’s auto plant, things probably look very different than what you might have seen on tours of your childhood, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. Why not get out there with your kids (or without kids at all), and take advantage of the opportunity to see vehicles that are Made in America? Many automakers are offering free tours; try out one of these en route to your vacation destination, or as part of a staycation plan this summer.

1. Ford Rouge Factory Tour in Dearborn, Michigan

Ford has gone to great lengths to provide a classic plant tour experience at the historic Rouge River plant, where the F-150 pickup is made. The walking tour has interactive activities and takes about forty-five minutes. You can also take an eighty-foot elevator ride up to the Observation Deck, where there’s a panoramic view of the complex. Other educational activities include a 360-degree movie experience featuring a virtual tour of blast furnaces, paint shops, and other colorful parts of production, all set to an original Detroit Symphony Orchestra score. Tours cost $11 for kids, $15 for adults, and take place Monday through Saturday, with the last tour bus leaving at 3 p.m. The tour can be combined with an excursion to the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village nearby.

2. Harley-Davidson Vehicle Operations in York, Pennsylvania

The Harley-Davidson plant here builds the Touring, Softail, CVO, and Trike models and makes parts such as fuel tanks and fenders. There’s a Kids Corner exhibit at the tour center for children under the age of twelve. A free factory tour lasts about an hour and is available Monday through Friday between 9 a.m. and 2 p.m. For $35, you can opt for the more tourist-friendly Steel Toe Tour, which takes you to such areas as the paint and polish zones, plus gives you a commemorative pin, a group photo, a safety vest, and a $5 coupon toward a gift shop purchase. This tour lasts two hours and is offered at 9:30 a.m. and noon, Monday through Thursday.

3. Mack Truck Macungie Assembly Operations in Macungie, Pennsylvania

Any Mack Truck fans in your household? There’s a walking tour of the Mack Truck plant, which mainly builds construction trucks, plus a Mack Trucks Historical Museum and a killer gift shop. Tours are offered on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, on the hour between 10 a.m. and 3 p.m. Reservations are encouraged.

4. Airstream Factory in Jackson Center, Ohio

Airstream trailers are back in fashion, and this tour shows how they’re made. “We really do put every one of those rivets in by hand,” the company notes. Tours are Monday through Thursday at 2 p.m., with Friday tours offered after normal production hours end. No appointment is necessary, although you can make an online reservation.

5. Subaru of Indiana Automotive in Lafayette, Indiana

Subaru of America’s only U.S. plant. Its tours take you on an elevated catwalk through the facility that builds the Outback, Legacy, and Tribeca, as well as some Camrys under a deal with Toyota. The free tours are offered at 9:00 a.m. on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. No kids under age ten are permitted.

6. General Motors Fairfax Assembly and Stamping Plant in Kansas City, Kansas

General Motors’ Fairfax plant offers a free tour that shows you the full assembly process from metal being made into body panels all the way through the first time a completed car is started. Products, which include the Buick LaCrosse and the Chevrolet Malibu, roll off the line every fifty-eight seconds.

7. Toyota Motor Manufacturing in Georgetown, Kentucky

At Toyota's Georgetown plant, check out the first U.S.-built Camry (from 1988) in the Visitor Center, then climb into an electric tram for a 1.5-hour comprehensive visit through the plant, which builds 2,000 Camry, Avalon, and Venza vehicles each day. Expect to hear a lot about the vaunted Toyota Production System while you do. Tours are free. The center is open Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., and reservations are strongly encouraged. No children under first-grade age (approximately six years old) are permitted.

8. Chevrolet Corvette Assembly Plant in Bowling Green, Kentucky

The Chevrolet Corvette is built here, and in addition to the National Corvette Museum nearby, there’s a walking plant tour (about a mile in all), during which you can watch the sports cars roll off the line. Cost is $7 per person, but if you’re a GM employee or retiree or an active military service member, you can take the tour for free. A $400 VIP tour of both the museum and the factory, which lasts up to four hours and gets you into the prep and delivery area, is also available. Reservations can be made online. Kids under seven are not allowed. Note: The tours, whether the cheap one or the pricey one, won’t be available again until late September as the facility gears up for the all-new 2014 Stingray.

9. Mercedes-Benz's only U.S. plant, in Tuscaloosa, Alabama

The Mercedes-Benz factory, which builds the GL-, M-, and R-Class vehicles, includes an “architectural showcase” of a museum with multimedia exhibits and a gift shop. Available on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 9:00 and 9:15 a.m. and 12:30 and 12:45 p.m., the tour costs $5 a head, and nobody under twelve is allowed on it. Reservations are recommended.

10. Hyundai Motor Manufacturing in Montgomery, Alabama

Hyundai Motor's Alabama plant, where the Sonata and Elantra are built, puts together 1,500 cars a day with the help of humans and “amazing robots.” The tram tour is free and kids over age six are allowed. Tours are available at 9:30 a.m., 12:30 p.m., and 2:00 p.m. on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, by advance reservation only.

11. Nissan North America in Smyrna, Tennessee

Take Nissan’s motorized tour through all stages of production, from steel sheet cutting to carpet to the exterior paint shop. The Leaf is built here, along with the Altima and Maxima. Tours are free and held on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. No kids under the age of ten are allowed.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

title: Surprise: Middle-Aged Car Buyers Rule
subTitle: Out of my way, youngster!
promoTeaserSmall: People aged 45 to 64 are by far the biggest group of new-car buyers. How's that for empowerment?
promoTeaser: People aged 45 to 64 are by far the biggest group of new-car buyers. How's that for empowerment?
metaTitle: Surprise: Middle-Aged Car Buyers Rule - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute
metaDescription: Surprise: Middle-Aged Car Buyers Rule, according to a new study from the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute. Read all about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

promoLarge.title: surprise middle aged car buyers rule

header.title: surprise middle aged car buyers rule

homepage.title: surprise middle aged car buyers rule

pageElements.text: Hey, Millennials, make way! Middle-aged people are by far the biggest group of new-car buyers. That’s the conclusion of a new study from the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI), which compared data from 2007 and 2011 to spot a strong aging trend in car shopper demographics.

The study found that the age range of “peak probability” for buying a new car is fifty-five to sixty-four. In 2011, one in every 14.6 drivers in that age group bought a new car. Only four years earlier, the biggest buying group was those aged thirty-five to forty-four, so the car-buying public is definitely getting older.
How many cars do the under-twenty-fives buy? It’s no shock, given the economic climate, that only one in 221.8 drivers in that group bought a new car in 2011.

By percentages, buyers thirty-five to forty-four bought 22 percent of all new cars in 2011, and those forty-five to fifty-four bought 26 percent. The fifty-five-to-sixty-four crowd were responsible for 23 percent of the new-car purchases.
So, who’s closing sales at the dealership? Almost half—49 percent—are solidly in middle age, and if you add in the thirty-five and up group, the total reaches 71 percent.
The UMTRI study recommended to marketers that they focus on the AARP-eligible buyers if they want “the highest probability of success per driver.”

A side issue here is that kids are less likely than ever to hurry and get a driver’s license at age sixteen. The UMTRI study pointed out that the number of twenty-to-twenty-four-year-olds with a driver’s license is down from 91.8 percent in 1983 to only 79.7 percent in 2011. Shocking!

Meanwhile, Granny is still clutching her license, and there are more Grannys on the road with every passing day. Drivers aged sixty to sixty-four with driver’s licenses jumped from 83.8 percent in 1983 to 92.7 percent in 2011.

It’s all very well to make jokes about Medicare Sleds, but I prefer to think of it as delayed gratification. It's time to stop thinking of ourselves as aging and watching our powers slip away. The middle-aged and older buyer is in the driver's seat now, coming into her own. You younger types: well, now you've got something to look forward to.

promoTeaser: "Auto styling is copy-cattish. The minute you buy it, every other manufacturer does it."
metaTitle: Group of Seven: Terri Barker - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Meet Terri Barker, a member of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven reader panel, and read some of her thoughts on life with cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Terri, 50, is a native of Jackson, Michigan, and currently lives in Ann Arbor, where she works for the Institute for Higher Learning. She drives a leased 2013 Chevrolet Equinox, but her dream car is a Jeep Wrangler.
“I want one with a hard top and a soft top,” she says. “I’ve always wanted one. It fits my personality.”
Terri’s family is composed of her husband, Jeffrey, and their three dogs, Mocha, Coal (both miniature pinschers), and Jax (a chihuahua/terrier mix). When Terri isn’t working, she enjoys playing golf.
Here’s what she has to say about some important issues in the auto world:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “It’s a concern that other drivers do it, but I don’t participate in it. I don’t text while driving because I’m too old to read my phone while driving. My eyesight is too bad. Why bother? I see other drivers doing everything, but texting is the worst. I would hate to see the federal government step in and do more to us, but somebody has to do something. I would like to see cell phones disabled when the car is running so you can make incoming and outgoing phone calls, but you couldn’t read texts and e-mails or check Facebook. Build it into the car.”

Auto Styling: “It’s copy-cattish. The minute you buy it, every other manufacturer does it. I am in favor of fewer options for car buyers—every manufacturer has twelve cars right now. They should be good at two or three, and that’s what they sell. No more. That makes the cars more unique.

“But, I do like what I’m seeing now. There are attractive options on the road. Nissan’s got quite a few. Chryslers are attractive. Ford has a lot of very attractive ones. Eye-catching ones. The Fusion and Escape have taken a good turn. I like the looks of the Ford C-Max Energi. That Kia Soul—you know, the one with the hamsters—is so ugly. Don’t like the squares. I don’t like boxes. The Honda Element was ugly, too.”
Gas Prices: “Way too high. I don’t understand it. Oil companies like Exxon should not be posting their profits while we are paying $4 a gallon. It costs $60 to $70 to fill up my Equinox.”
Technology/Autonomous Vehicles: “No, never! I’m a control freak. My heart starts racing just thinking about that.”
Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “I am not willing to buy one. It’s not convenient enough for me. I’m not sure how I would charge it. It would be a hassle doing all the research on those cars.
“I’m not concerned about green issues. Why? I don’t have a good answer for it. Maybe because I’m not leaving children behind and I’m not worried about that legacy.”

metaTitle: 2014 Subaru Forester 2.0XT Touring - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Subaru Forester 2.0XT Touring: read our "should you buy it?" review and comments from other staffers up in the Peanut Gallery. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $36,220 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter DOHC turbocharged horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 250 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Panoramic moonroof, 6.1-inch touchscreen with navigation system
Options I can’t live without: Adaptive cruise control and pre-collision braking (both part of EyeSight driver assist package, $2,400)
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Kia Sportage
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Subaru makes a business out of catering to two very different clientele: the boy-racer types who lust after sporty BRZs and Impreza WRXs, and practical, active drivers who put a high premium on safety. The all-new 2014 Subaru Forester 2.0XT Touring services the latter population and does an admirable job of it.

The 2014 Forester immediately sets itself apart from the crowd with its outstanding safety ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS). The Forester was a Top Safety Pick Plus winner and was one of only thirteen small SUVs to receive an overall Good rating on the IIHS test. The Forester we tested was packed with extra safety features as well, including lane departure warning, pre-collision braking, and the Subaru EyeSight system, which uses cameras to monitor the road and recognize hazardous situations.

Safe doesn’t have to mean boring, though. Our Forester’s 250-horsepower, 2.0-liter turbocharged engine provided plenty of steam to get this small SUV off the line, and the continuously variable transmission means that the Forester can constantly alter its gear ratios to operate at the engine’s most efficient revolutions per minute at a variety of speeds. The 2.0XT Touring model gets an impressive 28 mpg on the highway despite its all-wheel-drive system.

Standard all-wheel drive means the Forester will have characteristic Subaru surefootedness in bad weather, and the top-shelf models include features like hill descent control to give you an extra measure of confidence on tricky slopes.

Our Forester came with attractive leather-trimmed upholstery, which gave the cabin an upscale feel. The premium Harman/Kardon infotainment system looked like an aftermarket afterthought but it sounded like a dream. Subaru went the extra mile to win over drivers with the power liftgate and one-touch folding rear seats. Just a touch of a button in the trunk will give you a nearly flat load floor in seconds.

The Verdict:

Our 2.0XT is a no-brainer. The $36,000 price is a little hefty, but this crossover comes packed with the kind of safety and comfort features you'd expect in a luxury vehicle. Of course, you could always opt for a lower trim level, which still includes Subaru's confident all-wheel-drive system and enough airbags to keep anyone happy. But I think it would be a real shame to lose the turbo engine to a bout of frugality.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The first thing that struck me when I opened the Forester's doors was the floor mats. They are rubber with large lips that look like they could hold a couple liters of liquid. The interior was also predictably smart; everything felt like it was built to be driven well over the century mark on the odometer. I expected the driving experience to be the same feeling—prudent and slightly dull. I was proven wrong on a quick trip to Target. The 2.0-liter turbocharged engine was actually fun to drive and will make me think twice about this car.
Christina: I come from a Subaru-driving family. I love Subarus and I love the way this one drives. However, I didn’t feel comfortable behind the wheel at all. The steering wheel blocked the gauges. The color display over the touchscreen was distracting. The climate control knobs were confusing. And the ceiling? Despite the fact that I’m short, I felt my head was up too close to the headliner once I adjusted the driver’s seat so that I had a good view of the road. I'd hate to be a tall person driving this one.
Laura: I have known lots of people who drove Subarus, since we live in a wintry, and also a hippieish, climate here in Ann Arbor, Michigan. I haven’t considered owning one myself until now, because none of my friends’ cars were this good. This Subaru is utterly practical: I love the power liftgate, the stealth storage cubbies under the cargo floor, and the rubber mats everywhere that manage to look good while they make you start thinking about owning this Forester for ten years. The best part: while you’re driving around feeling smart and capable, like the kind of person who reads Consumer Reports for fun, notice how much fun you are having in this car.
Jean: I've recommended a Forester to three different people in the past month. That was before I knew it had—wait for it—a power liftgate! The Forester has been solid from Day One, ten years ago. It now feels a lot bigger and a lot more grown-up-looking inside (although the exterior still looks awkwardly adolescent). But it has a power liftgate!

pageElements.text: John Oates is an old friend of mine, and I’ve seen Hall & Oates perform many, many times, in venues from concert halls to open-air amphitheaters. It all started almost thirty years ago, when the phone rang. "Hi, this is John Oates. I like your writing, and I would love it if you’d come to our concert."
"Who is this?" I asked.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/FvoQPkDLniE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
"It’s John Oates, from Hall and Oates."
"Oh! I thought that band was called Howlin' Oats!"
"Nice," he said.

At first, I tried to beg off, being a hard-core Pink Floyd sort of girl, and he shamed me by saying, "We're going to be playing several dates. Surely you can make one of them, and I'll give you backstage passes." So I said, "Okay, sure, that sounds cool."

So six of us went. We had fantastic seats looking straight at the band, which was—Oh My God—the Saturday Night Live band with guitarist G.E. Smith fronting it and legendary bass player T-Bone Wolk. The band kicked off, and all night it was the rockingest show. I kept saying, "Oh, they do that? Oh, that's theirs?" and I was absolutely as hooked as all the rest of the fans who have made this duo the number-one duo in all of history. They’re bigger than Simon and Garfunkel, bigger than Jan and Dean, and still at it.

After that concert I really cemented a relationship with Oates when we both raced in the Renault LeCar Cup support race that backed one of the first Formula 1 races in downtown Detroit. He went on to club racing and raced karts and in Formula Ford, the Pro Sports 2000 series, and IMSA GTU, and he is a huge car fan. One year I even ran into him walking around the Detroit auto show with his wife and son. He was in town to perform at a black-tie auto function.

Over the years, I have seen them play an outdoor venue in Ohio in a field, I've hung out with band on their tour bus while it was parked in front of their hotel ready to leave, I’ve been with them in New York City in the recording studio while they worked on a Christmas special, and I have been to endless concerts. They never, ever get old. Now when they tour they add on a lot of casino shows, which can be surprisingly nice venues, including Motor City Casino in Detroit and FireKeepers in Battle Creek, where we interviewed him for this video. The backstage amenities here were pretty funny, as you can see when John offers me the perks of his stardom.

John and Daryl have developed distinctly different solo careers. John's is based out of Nashville, and his love of old R&B and blues is really in line with the kind of music I like. Daryl, on the other hand, developed an online show called Live from Daryl’s House in his farmhouse, where he invites every kind of musician from reggae kings Toots and the Maytals to the legendary Smokey Robinson to the electric Sharon Jones of the Dap-Kings. The series has just expanded to be on VH1 cable TV on Saturday mornings. His voice is only somewhat dimmed over the years; it is still pretty monster.

When John called to say he was going to be in town, he gave us passes for the Jean Knows Cars staff, and as usual, we had the time of our lives, surrounded by a roomful of people who were on their feet. On this video, he talks about what a rock star drives and his favorite music.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: This is starting to feel like the golden age of safety technology. It’s exciting to think that such basic operations as braking can be optimized by the use of advanced wireless communications technology. That’s just what Ford is doing with its research to improve brake lights.

We’ve had our eye on connected vehicles for a while now, and we’re always excited to hear about new applications for car-to-car communication. This week, the excitement comes from Ford’s experimental brake light warning technology, currently in testing as part of the Safe Intelligent Mobility-Testfield Germany (simTD) project.

The technology consists of a high-tech brake light that can communicate with other cars in emergency braking situations to help reduce reaction time for other drivers. The Electronic Brake Light works by transmitting a wireless signal to cars behind it, alerting them of episodes of heavy braking by illuminating a light on their dashboards.

In 41,000 hours of testing, Ford has seen that the technology can help drivers react faster to the emergency braking of cars ahead and help them “mitigate or avoid” collisions. The testing was done with specially equipped versions of the Ford S-Max (right), a small three-row vehicle sold in Europe.

The brake light is just one of twenty safety systems that Ford is testing in Aachen, Germany, as part of the simTD project. Other systems include in-car Internet access and a public traffic management system that would give drivers an exact traffic prediction based on existing traffic scenarios and travel time. These technologies may still be a long way off from real-world implementation, but it’s nice to know that in-car technology won’t stop with touchscreen navigation systems.

pageElements.text: Go to Part Two of this report
Just in case you were getting a little sick of me and my precious driveway, my bald husband, and my hairy dogs…Wait! Has my life turned into a George Booth cartoon?!?...
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/lW1j4kGYVV4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

I thought you’d like to see my new girlfriends again, the G-7 consumer panel who won our contest (in which they had to pay for everything themselves) to join me at the Detroit Auto Show last January. Four of our seven fab friends jumped at my offer to fly them back in to test cars in The Driveway, the very same driveway that old Louie wishes I would pave all the way down the lane to ease her old paws.  (The other three had unavoidable conflicts. Next time!)

Anna Eby came from Texas, Val Luepke blew in from Minnesota, and two of the original Michigander panelists—Dolly Tittle and Jacqueline Dufek—welcomed three local friends of JKC, Janet Popper, Terri Barker, and Heather Sager, to test some of the hottest crossover vehicles on the market. I expected a day of friendly disagreements, budding friendships, and unladylike behavior. The tone was set by senior editor Molly Jean, who chauffeured the G-7 around all weekend in a party van, the fifteen-passenger Mercedes-Benz Sprinter, with irrepressible good humor.

Then it was time to drive. The Group of Seven spans a variety of ages and lifestyles, from young and entry-level buyers through parents of small children to the middle-aged and empty nesters. Our plan was to try out the Ford Escape, the Honda CR-V, the Kia Sportage, and the Buick Encore from a consumer’s point of view. We spent a long day taking turns driving them around the country roads and on the interstate, loading up the vehicles with typical family gear, and scrutinizing window stickers.
The women got to know the four crossovers inside and out, checking everything from highway acceleration to cabin amenities, along with ride and handling and, of course, price.
And, of course, they had very strong opinions. Watch the video to see what they thought of the cars.

It was never our intention to pick a winner—instead, we had a great time talking about the pros and cons of each of these crossovers. I hope it helps you get to know the four vehicles and the seven members of our G-7 a little better. More adventures are being planned as we speak. Stay tuned.

pageElements.text: Are you thinking of buying a brand-new Mercedes-Benz but are worried that your expensive luxury car just won’t be eye-catching enough? It’s a fair concern. Mercedes-Benz is very good at building capable, attractive, luxurious cars, but they do tend more toward understated elegance than flashy excess. You worked hard for that car, though. Why not brag a little?

For the less discreet Mercedes owner, the company now offers an Illuminated Star accessory, which is just what it sounds like. The add-on turns the bold Mercedes-Benz sport grille, featuring a large three-pointed star, into an LED-laden, light-up announcement of your taste in cars.

The carmaker’s website describes the illuminated star as “subtle” and “sophisticated.” Those aren’t the first adjectives that jumped to my mind, but we can at least all agree that this accessory is subtler and more sophisticated than, say, a Lamborghini Gallardo. See it here.

Adding this piece of bling to your Mercedes will run you $480. It is available for installation on model year 2006 and newer CLS coupes and 2014 or newer E-Class, 2013 or newer GL-Class, and 2012 or newer M-Class vehicles. Leased cars, too! Mercedes says the light-up star will come to even more models in the future.

Fortunately or unfortunately, U.S. government lighting regulations say the star can’t light up while you’re driving, so it’ll only shine when the car is parked and unlocked for forty seconds or for five seconds after a door is opened. Still plenty of time to make sure everyone knows you’re riding in the lap of luxury.

title: Minivan Buyer's Guide
subTitle: Get one of these while you still can
promoTeaserSmall: Feeling reluctantly practical? A chauffeur of many kids? Join me in shopping the classic minivan.
promoTeaser: Feeling reluctantly practical? A chauffeur of many kids? Join me in shopping the classic minivan.
metaTitle: Minivan Buyer's Guide - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Minivan Buyer's Guide tells you about all the true minivans on the market and what I like best about each. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Talk about your culturally loaded terms. “Minivan” is right up there, dividing families, causing people to apologize or self-deprecate while they drive. Not me. I proudly stand behind the big-box transporters and tell the world that I love minivans.

I don’t just love them because I have a family of six, and we need the space. I don’t just love them because I happen to fit the demographic of the Earth Mother/field trip driver. I love minivans because they are truly a living room on wheels, able to give each passenger his or her own personal space, able to carry it all and still, with their front-wheel-drive setup and great visibility, feel like you’re driving a car. They’re not the sportiest or most fun to drive. Hey, as I say to those who ride in my second and third seats, life isn’t always just about fun.
And then I laugh maniacally, and it turns out that life is about fun after all.

Whether you are a minivan partisan or a reluctant convert, here is your rundown on all the current minivans that fit the strict definition of the category. They seat seven with three rows of seats; the seats reconfigure easily for various uses; they’re more or less refrigerator shaped. There are fewer than there used to be. Having said that, this is a collection of time-tested, tried and true vehicles. Their makers have been at it a while and know how to make what you want and need.

But we may be at a crossroads here—and I am talking to you other minivan fans out there who gave the rolling rectangles the best years of your lives. Rumor has it that the some of these minivans may be coming to the end of their life spans. There are rumors about Chrysler moving on to a more crossover-like vehicle and the Sedona going away altogether soon. None of that is happening for 2014, but we're just saying: grab on to the tail end of a legend, and enjoy these true minivans while they last.

2013 Chrysler Town & Country

Feel like Patrician Mom carrying a full set of Honor Roll bumper stickers in your designer handbag

This is probably the one you think of when you think “minivan.” Now in its fifth generation, its history goes back to the late 1980s when it rolled out as the luxury version of the Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager.  It’s still the top-end Chrysler, with items such as rain-sensing wipers, Nappa leather, and a heated steering wheel that you normally find on luxury cars. You’ll see lots of these minivans lined up at the swim club and the local private schools. Sadly, it no longer comes with those fake-woodgrain sides. They’d look nice and retro now.

Base prices: $31,525 (Touring), $32,990 (S), $34,525 (Touring-L), $41,740 (Limited)
Engine: 3.6-liter 24-valve V-6, 283 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Safety: Seven airbags, SafetyTec package ($1,695 on Touring and S, standard on Touring-L and Limited; includes blind spot monitoring, rear park assist), backup camera
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick, 2013 Detroit News Readers’ Choice Awards Best Family Hauler, top-ranking minivan in 2013 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study
My favorite standard features: Backup camera, Stow ‘n Go easy-flip-down seating (as shown at left), three-zone climate control, four rear storage bins, second-row video screens with DVD player (standard on the Touring and Touring-L models)
Options you should be sure to get: Navigation for the standard touchscreen media center ($895 on S, $995 on Touring and Touring-L, standard on Limited), blind spot monitoring ($1,695 in the SafetyTec package on Touring and S models, standard on Touring-L and Limited), heated second-row seats to lull your little guys to sleep ($430 in Driver Convenience Group package on Touring-L, standard on Limited)
How much space? 143.8 cubic feet maximum; 33.0 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2013 Dodge Grand Caravan

Your ride if you’re saving up for college…or a trip around the world

Budget-conscious parents can choose this version of the Chrysler minivan, which starts way down in economy-car price territory and tops out where the Town & Country begins. Despite its rational price structure, the Grand Caravan is available with lots of the same features as the Town & Country, such as park assist, rain-sensing wipers, and heated front and second-row seats, if you’re willing to pay the option prices. It’s worth doing the math in detail, since many options on the lower-end Grand Caravan models become standard on the higher trim levels. Down at the base American Value Package end of the lineup, there are old-school manual sliding doors. Hey, don’t complain! I remember the days when minivans only had one manual sliding door, and I drove them five miles in the snow, uphill both ways…

Base prices: $20,990 (American Value Package, or AVP), $24,190 (SE), $27,690 (SXT), $29,790 (Crew), $30,990 (R/T)
Engine: 3.6-liter 24-valve V-6, 283 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Safety: Seven airbags, Safety Sphere package ($1,400 on Crew and R/T; includes blind spot monitoring, front and rear park assist), backup camera (SXT)
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard features: Stow ‘n Go easy flip-down seating (on all but AVP model), dual glove box, dual power sliding doors (only on SXT, Crew, and R/T)
Options you should be sure to get: Second- and third-row video screens with BluRay/DVD player (shown at left; $2,490 on ST, Crew, and R/T), or economize with second-row-only video and DVD ($1,495 on SXT, Crew, and R/T), UConnect hands-free package ($590 on AVP, $194 on SE and SXT, standard on Crew and R/T)
How much space? 143.8 cubic feet maximum; 33.0 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2014 Honda Odyssey

So nice! And so many of them everywhere you look!

The first Honda Odyssey seen in the U.S. market was more like a tall wagon, and it didn’t pose much of a threat to the dominant Chrysler minivans. The current full-boat Odyssey came out in 1998, a little late to the U.S. minivan party, but it has become ubiquitous since then. If you don’t believe that, go look in the parking lot of any preschool or any middle-school sporting event. It is also available as an eight-passenger vehicle if you get a second-row bench seat. Only the Toyota Sienna can say the same. With a slick exterior, a high level of interior amenities, and the Cult of Honda hanging over it, it’s the go-to minivan choice for the same people who would only look at Honda sedans. The 2014 Odyssey will be in dealerships on July 2.

New for 2014: Standard Bluetooth HandsFreeLink, Pandora interface, SMS text messaging, and four-way power passenger’s seat; every Odyssey also gets a six-speed automatic transmission
Base prices: $29,655 (LX), $32,955 (EX), $36,455 (EX-L), $38,055(EX-L RES), $38,455 (EX-L Navi), $42,710 (Touring), $45,280 (Touring Elite)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve SOHC i-VTEC V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway

Safety: Six airbags, rear-view camera, active head restraints, electronic brake-force distribution, vehicle stability assist with traction control, Lane Watch blind spot display (EX models and up), forward collision warning and lane departure warning (EX-L, EX-L RES and up)
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick, 2013 U.S. News & World Report Best Minivan for Families
My favorite standard features: One-motion folding third-row “magic” seat (Touring and Touring Elite models also have folding center armrest), cool box under the instrument panel that holds a six-pack of drinks (standard on EX-L, Touring, Touring Elite), Ultrawide 16.2-inch rear entertainment system with a split screen (on Touring Elite only), removable center console with (get this!) a flip-up trash bag ring (shown at left; EX models and up), multifunction second-row seat that slides up so the front passenger can reach back to the child safety seat installed on it (EX models and up)

Options you should be sure to get: What you need to do with the Odyssey is move up to a higher trim level to get the best goodies, such as: push-button start (EX and up); multi-angle rear-view camera (EX-L Navi, Touring, and up); and that already iconic on-board vacuum (standard on Touring Elite only)
How much space? (2013 model) 148.5 cubic feet maximum; 38.4 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2014 Kia Sedona

Plain vanilla, but sometimes vanilla is a good flavor

The pundits declared the Sedona dead, but it’s got a pulse, after its own fashion. The 2014 Kia Sedona is available already because the Korean automaker took 2013 off and didn’t make a Sedona last year. Its pricing is up from the structure of past model years, but it’s still competitively reasonable. However, the looks are not; this might win the crown for least interesting design. Those of you who want a non-tarted-up, basic minivan that gets you there and fits everyone and everything, here you go. I have to admit that I like knowing it’s still out there.

Base prices: $26,750 (LX), $31,650 (EX)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 269 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Safety: Six airbags, backup warning system, auto-dimming mirror with backup display (part of $1,900 Power package for LX, standard on EX)
My favorite standard features: Backup warning sensor that beeps when you get too close to an object, front-row extendable side table, LED running lights (new for 2014)
Options you should be sure to get: Dual power sliding doors (part of $1,900 Power package for LX, standard on EX)
How much space? 141.5 cubic feet maximum; 32.2 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2013 Nissan Quest

Your kids might feel slightly less embarrassed to be seen with you. Or, depending on their design sensibilities, slightly more

Nissan is trying really, really hard to make its minivan look unlike a minivan. Give it up; it’s a minivan, folks. On the plus side, the Quest has lots and lots of glass, which shows that Nissan takes people seriously when they say they want good visibility in a minivan. Which is what every minivan owner I know says they want. The back-seat passengers will appreciate optional dual opening glass moonroofs (below left) and second-row power windows, because in most minivans they get little to no fresh air back there. They’ll also like the fact that the second and third rows raise gradually like theater seats. Clean-air types will enjoy the Advanced Climate Control System with a grape polyphenol filter and a purifier, meant to cut down on allergens in the cabin. My standards must be low, but this wouldn’t be a deal maker for me. Then again, it probably would be for anybody dealing with allergies in their families. It’s on the LE model.

Base prices: $26,835 (S), $30,585 (SV), $34,365 (SL), $43,485 (LE)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 260 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/25 mpg highway
Safety: Six airbags, rear-view monitor, blind spot warning, Around View monitor (LE only)
My favorite standard features: Second-row power windows will be a hit with kids, especially on long rides; tire pressure monitor with an Easy-Fill alert that tells you when you’ve hit proper tire inflation; power rear liftgate (standard on SL and LE)
Options you should be sure to get: DVD entertainment system (optional on SV and SL, standard on LE) and eleven-inch color monitor; manual blinds for the second and third row (LE)
How much space? 108.4 cubic feet maximum; 37.1 cubic feet behind the third row of seats

2013 Toyota Sienna

So many versions, choices, price points, there’s got to be one of these for everybody

The Sienna comes in front- or all-wheel-drive versions. That’s a big differentiator between it and its competitor. Another is the availability of a “sporty” SE model with side skirting, nineteen-inch alloy wheels, a lower stance with a sport-tuned suspension, and smoked taillights. And yet another is that you can configure the Sienna as an eight-passenger vehicle by having a second-row bench seat (the Odyssey has this, too, but the others don’t). From under $28,000 for the base model all the way up above $40,000 for the Limited, if you have any desire for a minivan, you should be able to configure one of these to suit you.

Base prices: $27,430 (L), $30,980 (LE), $34,570 (SE), $34,355 (XLE), $40,950 (Limited)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 266 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/25 mpg highway (FWD); 16/23 mpg (AWD)
Safety: Seven airbags; Star Safety System, which includes electronic brake-force distribution, brake assist, vehicle stability control, traction control; rear parking assist (front and rear on Limited model), blind spot monitor with cross-traffic alert (on XLE and Limited)
Accolades: 2013 IIHS Top Safety Pick; 2013 IntelliChoice awards for Best Overall Value of the Year, Highest Retained Value in Its Class, and Lowest Maintenance Costs
My favorite standard features: Tip Up and Long Slide second-row seats that move to suit your cargo- or people-carrying needs; three-zone automatic climate control, rear sunshades, multi-information display with backup camera (all three are standard on LE and up)
Options you should be sure to get: Ten-speaker premium JBL sound system with voice-activated navigation (on XLE), rear-seat Dual View Entertainment system with split 16.4-inch screens, independently powered dual sliding moonroofs (included on Limited)
