title: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG
promoTitle: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG
promoTeaserSmall: Its EPA numbers had been calculated based on Fusion Hybrid. Revised C-Max mpg: 45/43/40.
promoTeaser: Its EPA numbers had been calculated based on Fusion Hybrid. Revised C-Max mpg: 45/43/40.
metaTitle: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG
metaDescription: Ford C-Max Hybrid Drops a Few MPG: Ford has announced it has cut the fuel economy numbers on the popular crossover. Find out why at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In the pageant that is fuel economy, the hybrids are the glamorous contestants, offering the complete package: the peace of mind of a gasoline engine along with the cost- and fuel-saving qualities of a battery. When it came onto the stage last year, what could have been more promising an entrant than the Ford C-Max Hybrid? It boasted neat, tidy, and damned impressive EPA fuel economy numbers of 47 mpg in town, 47 mpg on the highway, and 47 mpg combined. On every form of media from radio to YouTube, there has been a barrage of advertising about how that 47/47/47 was better than the C-Max’s archrival, the Toyota Prius V, which “only” claims 44/40/42 mpg.

Apparently 47/47/47 was a little too neat and tidy. This afternoon, Ford downgraded its numbers for the C-Max Hybrid. Henceforth, the C-Max Hybrid gets a combined 43 mpg, according to the automaker. Its full set of fuel economy numbers: 45 mpg in town, 40 mpg on the highway, and 43 combined.

Here’s How It Happened

In a press conference today, Ford’s spokesman said it all started when the company tested the Fusion Hybrid, a sedan, and used its fuel economy numbers on the label for the C-Max Hybrid, which has a crossover body style. That was not an error or a deception on Ford’s part. As Ford explained, the EPA rules work on a “general label” principle, requiring auto companies to test only one vehicle in each family so that every single variant of every car doesn’t have to be tested. The automaker is supposed to define a family by common engine, transmission, and weight class, and then test the highest-volume vehicle.
There are no plans to change the Fusion Hybrid’s 47/47/47 mpg label.

The C-Max Energi plug-in hybrid and the Fusion Energi count as a family, too, but of that pair, Ford tested the C-Max Energi, not the Fusion, because the C-Max is a bigger seller. Ford’s spokesman said. For that reason, the Fusion Energi could very well be getting better fuel economy than its label states, he noted.

Cash Going Out to 2013 C-Max Hybrid Owners

Ford will make one-time payments to 2013 C-Max Hybrid buyers: $550 for buyers and $325 for those who have leased the vehicle. Letters are going out to everyone who got a C-Max Hybrid with a 47/47/47 mpg sticker.

And Changes Coming for the 2014 Model

Ford said it will make changes to the 2014 model, out later this year, including transmission changes and modifications to make the C-Max Hybrid’s body more aerodynamic.

Just a month ago, Ford issued a “software upgrade” to help its C-Max, Fusion, and Lincoln MKZ hybrid models get better fuel economy. Among those were an increase in top speed in electric-only mode, to 85 mph from the previous 62 mph, and some climate control changes such as shortening engine warmup time and reducing the electric fan’s speed to cut energy consumption.

This Has Been Known for a While...

You could have figured that out sooner, though, by simply visiting the My Fuel Economy section of the EPA’s fueleconomy.gov website. Here, 100 C-Max Hybrid owners have reported their actual fuel economy in the real world: an average of 39.1 mpg. Now, let’s consider what kind of person would keep that kind of close track and go report it to an EPA database. I would stereotype him or her as a detail-oriented person with a deep personal interest in fuel economy, or what you might call a careful driver. And they came up with an 8-mpg differential.
Consumer Reports, too, tested the 2013 C-Max Hybrid and reported 37 mpg overall, which it called “excellent but well short of the EPA's 47 mpg.”

Hyundai/Kia Have Been Here Before

Ford is not the first automaker to have this problem. Hyundai and Kia lowered fuel economy numbers late last year on 900,000 vehicles sold between 2010 and October 31, 2012. The wrong numbers were blamed on faulty calibration of ratings back home in South Korea, and the adjustment reduced the whole lineup’s average fuel economy by three percent, from 27 mpg to 26 mpg. The biggest impact was cutting the 40-mpg highway mileage claims on the Hyundai Accent, Elantra, and Sonata HEV and Kia Veloster. They’re all now in the high 30s.

The company went a step further and offered to pay owners back for the extra gas they had to buy, plus a fifteen percent penalty—a move that could cost Hyundai/Kia a total of $100 million by the time it’s all over.

More about How EPA Testing Works

The EPA is also reportedly looking at changes to the way it figures fuel economy. The way it stands now, the automakers themselves test for fuel economy, and the EPA confirms that by actually testing about fifteen percent of the cars on the market itself, under lab conditions, but also reviews test data from the automakers to spot potential problems. The EPA said Ford followed the rules and is not at fault for this C-Max issue.

A check of the EPA testing parameters shows that “city driving” is tested at an average 21.2 mph, while “highway driving” is tested at an average of 48.3 mph. The EPA also states that “your mileage may vary” is not just a saying. What kinds of roads you drive on, how you accelerate and brake, how fast you go, what the weather and terrain are like, and what you might be carrying or towing can all have a big effect on your fuel economy.

Should You Care?

Well, or how much should you care? Yes, you might buy the C-Max Hybrid because of the great fuel economy, and be disappointed that it hasn't quite gotten where the claims led you to believe, but it’s still probably so much better than whatever you probably drove before. The bottom line may be that you should choose your next car based on a whole lot of factors, not just on one selling point, no matter how compelling it looks at the time.

title: Harvest Tour: Taste the U.S.A.
promoTeaserSmall: Visit a few fruit and vegetable capitals! Eat your way to a better feel for our nation's variety.
promoTeaser: Visit a few fruit and vegetable capitals! Eat your way to a better feel for our nation's variety.
metaTitle: Harvest Tour: Taste the U.S.A. - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Harvest Tour: Taste the U.S.A. See the U.S.A. through its fruit and vegetable capitals, and gain a new appreciation for the regional specialties you'll find at festivals and farmer's markets. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: My friend Maggie doesn’t consider her summer complete until she has enjoyed at least one dinner featuring only three things: ripe locally grown potatoes, tomatoes, and corn. What a great tradition, just right for our Michigan harvest season. And that makes me think about all the ripe locally grown foods out there where you live, or a short drive away.

One of the best things about traveling in summer is the ability to sample whatever the local specialties are. It’s all too easy to stay on the Interstate highways and eat at chain restaurants, completely missing the regional flavor of each area you pass through. If you don’t believe regional differences are still out there, just go to a farmer’s market sometime. You’ll feel proud, patriotic, relieved, but mostly, you’ll feel hungry.

In honor of the harvest season, here are some of the slightly tacky (in a good way) World Capitals of various fruits and vegetables around the country. Some of them have annual festivals, and some are just good places to pick up the produce from the local stores. Maybe you should visit the ones near you—or make them part of your vacation plans for next spring and summer.

And take the family! Kids love any kind of festival, and teenagers will appreciate the ironic humor value. (I clearly remember posing, in great humor, for a photo next to the Giant Artichoke statue in California. Wish I could find it now.)

1. Hadley, Massachusetts: Asparagus Capital

Yankee magazine tells us that the Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts got the Asparagus Capital moniker back in the 1920s. Although the crop’s current importance to the area isn’t what it once was, at Barstow’s Dairy Store and Bakery, you can buy or lunch on local produce, and there is still an Asparagus Festival. In 2013, it was June 2 and 3, and it featured a “Spearit” Gala feast prepared by area chefs.

2. Kennett Square, Pennsylvania: Mushroom Capital

This is Pennsylvania Dutch country, and they don’t mess around when it comes to quaint ways to spend your tourism dollar. But this is legit: A full 65 percent of all mushrooms grown in the United States come from this area. The Mushroom Festival is always the week after Labor Day, so there’s time to get there this year. An amateur mushroom appetizer cookoff is part of the fun (six finalists have already been named, making such delicacies as grilled crimini reuben sliders and hot shiitake sausage stuffed mushrooms), and there’s a parade. Sorry to say that the mascot’s name is Fun Gus.

3. Windsor, Florida: Zucchini Capital

The Zucchini Pageant is over for another year, the Zucchqueen has been crowned, the Famous Kazucchini Marching Band has played, and the Zucchinithon Fun Run is all done. But don't worry; it'll all be back in 2014. Those of us in the north aren’t anywhere near done eating zucchini yet, but in Florida, the Windsor Zucchini Festival has happened in early May for a quarter-century. Fried zucchini, zucchini ice cream, the cook-a-zuke contest? Not to be missed.

4. Vidalia, Georgia: Sweet Onion Capital

The Vidalia Onion Festival will be held over April 20-21 next year, and it will see a dozen Georgia chefs competing for the Golden Onion award. The onions can be shipped anywhere, but here’s an opportunity to see an onion farm up close—not to mention appreciate the cooking of chefs from the most chic restaurants from Atlanta to Savannah.

5. Cordele, Georgia: Watermelon Capital

Crisp County. What a great place name for the number-four watermelon-growing county in the United States. Despite its position off the watermelon podium, Cordele, Georgia, still claims Watermelon Capital of the World status, priding itself on the size and juiciness of its seedless red melons. Despite that, I don’t even have to tell you they have a watermelon seed spitting contest, do I? The Watermelon Days Festival takes place in late June. There’s also a watermelon parade and, for some reason, watermelon dance lessons.

6. Houghton, Michigan: Thimbleberry Capital

There’s no festival with parades and crowds to celebrate the Thimbleberry Capital, just a lot of natural beauty in the area, on the Keewenaw Peninsula that juts out into Lake Superior. These soft berries, native to the Great Lakes, don’t travel well, so it’s worth a visit to get them at the source. Or order jam online from the Thimbleberry Jam Lady. What are they? The thimbleberry is a wild berry that looks similar to a raspberry and tastes like heaven.

7. Hoopeston, Illinois: Sweet Corn Capital

The Hoopeston sports teams have proudly worn ears of corn on their uniforms since the Great Depression, and the Cornjerker mascot (“Jerky” for short) is part of the area’s cultural heritage. As the city fathers put it, “A slender stalk of sweet corn has been Hoopeston’s backbone for more than a century.”

The 2013 National Sweet Corn Festival this year, titled “Rumble in the Corn,” is the seventieth annual. It’s happening all Labor Day weekend. Besides the expected beer tents and beauty contests, the local Jaycees cook up fifty tons of sweet corn with an antique steam engine (!) and distribute the corn free every afternoon.

8. Emerson, Arkansas: PurpleHull Pea Capital

What’s a PurpleHull pea? Just about what it sounds like. Of African origin, the peas are members of the same pea family as the more famous black-eyed peas. Every June, there’s a cookoff (sponsored by Big Daddy’s Hot Water Cornbread) and a shelling competition, but if you’re looking for a little more excitement, a garden tiller world championship race with a $1,000 prize. They’re not kidding about the “world” part here: the 1995 event was won by a contestant from Holland. The PurpleHull Pea Festival takes place at the end of June each year.

9. Crystal City, Texas: Spinach Capital

Crystal City will get a bit of an argument from Alma, Arkansas, for Spinach Capital honors, but Crystal City’s got a statue of Popeye, so that should settle it. This small town is home to a large Del Monte processing plant. The 2013 festival takes place November 7-10.

10. Jay, Oklahoma: Huckleberry Capital

Just as Huckleberry Finn was Tom Sawyer gone wild, huckleberries are like blueberries gone wild. They’re not a cultivated berry that you’ll find at Kroger; all the more reason to adventure to where they grow wild. Or plan your next Fourth of July weekend around the Huckleberry Festival. There, they do huckleberries to death: huckleberry pie, huckleberry lemonade, even huckleberry milkshakes. For a change of pace, there’s a root beer chugalug competition. Free ice cream with huckleberry sauce in the town square, too. Huckleberry products are for sale at the town museum to take home with you.

11. Rocky Ford, Colorado: Sweet Melon Capital

This place is about more than just melons. It's about America. See, a guy named George Washington Swink had a vision that started when he opened a trading post near the Santa Fe trail in 1870. All went well until the Santa Fe railroad was built. The enterprising Mr. Swink simply moved the post a few miles so it was closer to the tracks, and that's when he brought the town of Rocky Ford into existence. In his spare time when he wasn’t founding the bank, serving as the first mayor, and representing the area as state senator, Swink also started the town on the lucrative business of melon farming. Because of him, Rocky Ford claims the title of Melon Capital of the World. This Edison wannabe even invented a cantaloupe crate that’s still in use today.

Celebrate old Swink’s genius by dropping by Watermelon Day, part of the Arkansas Valley Fair since back in Swink’s day. It’s the second full week in August every year. Rocky Ford watermelon and cantaloupe are still grown in quantity here, and the Growers Association claims it’s the 4,200-foot altitude with its hot days and cool nights that makes them special. You can order direct from Knapp Farms of Rocky Ford and get them shipped to you, but what a nice road trip this would be.

12. Jacksonville, Texas: Tomato Capital

Who would have pictured an East Texas city as Tomato Capital of the World? More in character: it’s the home of the World’s Largest Bowl of Salsa, certified by the Guinness people. Gotta see that! The festival takes place on the second Saturday in June and features tomato eating and mashing contests, tomato peeling, and a tomato shoot. Tomatoes used to leave Jacksonville in special refrigerated rail cars, but you can take them home in your own car these days.

13. Hatch, New Mexico: Chile Pepper Capital

Chile facts learned while finding the Chile Pepper capital: one fresh medium-size green chile pod has as much Vitamin C as six oranges. Even better: hot chile peppers speed up the metabolism by triggering a “thermodynamic burn” in the body. Nuclear! The Hatch Chile Fest takes place over the last weekend in August and includes the expected cookoff as well as a mariachi competition.

14. Yuma, Arizona: Lettuce Capital

Here is another unlikely candidate for World Capital, but indeed Yuma, Arizona, does have an annual Lettuce Days festival, and the next one is March 1-2, 2014. Local produce, celebrity chefs, and a harvest dinner are all scheduled. Two great cooking contests are Make Me Eat It, giving $250 to the cook who can present the most desirable healthy kid’s meal—warning, the judges are kids—and Healthy Eating the RV Way, paying $250 to the cook who can make the best road salad using only five ingredients. For those of us in the north, who aren’t even dreaming about harvests yet in early March, this green event would be part of a perfect vacation.

15. Blackfoot, Idaho: Potato Capital

If you want the recipe for potato chip cookies, or just aspire to have your picture taken next to a baked potato the size of a Chevrolet Suburban, then the Idaho Potato Museum is for you. One Trip Advisor reviewer noted, “I particularly liked the tuxedo jacket made of burlap potato sacking, and the Dan Quayle exhibit.” Looking for more of a party atmosphere? Twenty miles north in the town of Shelley, you’ll find Spud Day, happening on September 21 this year. On the schedule are a Spud Tug, a potato picking contest, and free baked potatoes handed out at noon.

16. Castroville, California: Artichoke Capital

At the time I visited the Giant Artichoke restaurant in Castroville as an eighteen-year-old, I had never actually eaten an artichoke. I remember the insanely delicious deep-fried artichokes as if it were yesterday. (I also had a date milkshake and haven't forgotten that, either.) This is the kind of place that mixes kitsch with sincere homage to the agricultural side of the Golden State. Plus, who doesn't want a photo of the family in front of a giant artichoke? There's also an Artichoke Festival here, in mid-May.

17. Redlands, California: Navel Orange Capital

Redlands doesn't celebrate its history as navel orange capital with a big, splashy festival. Instead, this town that is home to the University of Redlands features a Market Night every Thursday that draws crowds. Join them, and try out the local citrus and other fresh treats.

18. Wenatchee, Washington: Apple Capital

I have to point out that Michigan has some of the world's best apples. Nevertheless, Washington State has some great ones, too. The town of Wenatchee also spends eleven days celebrating the industry with an Apple Blossom Festival. The next one starts on April 24 and culminates on May 4 with an Ultimate Apple Pie & Dessert Bakeoff competition.

Safety features: Front and side airbags for driver and passenger, side impact protection door beams, tire pressure monitoring system, electronic stability control

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7DhkyvTg9-c?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The Beetle Turbo uses the same 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbocharged engine that’s in the Volkswagen GTI, among other VW products. In our test car, the engine makes 200 horsepower, but a recent engine update bumped Beetle Turbo models up to 210 horsepower. Volkswagen says the update shaves 0.2 second off the Beetle Turbo’s 0-to-60-mph time and translates to a four to eight percent fuel economy savings.

• Volkswagen is tweaking the Beetle convertible lineup for 2014. The Beetle Turbo convertible will be rebadged as the Beetle R-Line Convertible. Volkswagen’s R-Line offerings are performance inspired, but this new designation doesn’t come with any powertrain changes. It's the same old Turbo with a brand-new name.

• The Beetle convertible lineup features three engine choices. In addition to this car’s turbocharged four-cylinder powerplant, there’s a 2.5-liter five-cylinder engine that makes 170 horsepower and starts at $25,790, including destination, and a TDI model with a 2.0-liter 140-horsepower diesel-burning engine. The diesel Beetle costs a little more (starting at $28,690), but it’s rated at 28 mpg in the city and 41 mpg on the highway.

• This Beetle is one of the few convertibles on the market to offer a rear seat, and it’s surprisingly roomy. An adult might feel cramped, but most kids will fit just fine.

• It’s hard to name many direct competitors to the Beetle convertible, since so much of its appeal comes from its unique history and design, but check out other small, quirky convertibles like the Fiat 500c or the Mini Cooper convertible.

• For $30,665, you might expect a nicer interior (this Beetle is awash in plastic and leatherette), but if you ever feel ripped off, just remember: you’re driving a convertible. The power folding top is fully automatic and can operate while the vehicle is moving at speeds of up to 31 mph.

• Style features: Three-color adjustable ambient lighting, leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel and leather-wrapped shift knob, eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, leather seating surfaces (standard in Turbo with Sound and Navigation), and gloss black exterior mirror housings, available in special 50s, 60s, and 70s edition decade-themed models.

title: Safest Places to Drive?
promoTeaserSmall: Allstate study names the U.S. cities with the fewest (and most) crashes per person.
promoTeaser: Allstate study names the U.S. cities with the fewest (and most) crashes per person.
metaTitle: Safest Places to Drive? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Safest Places to Drive? New Allstate study says which of 200 biggest cities has the least--and the most--collisions. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Automotive studies are thick on the ground. In terms of how many there are—and how few are really interesting—they’re right up there with awards shows. To this list, you might add the Allstate Insurance Company’s ninth annual America’s Best Drivers Report—or you might not, depending on how much you enjoy trivia.

The Allstate report has named Fort Collins, Colorado, “America’s Safest Driving City” for the third year in a row. A forgettable statistic—unless you live in Fort Collins, perhaps. But consider that Allstate is basing this honor on the actual frequency of crashes on which claims were filed. The average driver in Fort Collins gets into a crash every 13.9 years. That’s 28.2 percent less often than the national average of ten years. The next four cities on the list are Boise, Idaho; Sioux Falls, South Dakota; Brownsville, Texas; and Madison, Wisconsin.
Source: Allstate Newsroom

But cut to the chase, you say. Which were the cities at the bottom of the Best Drivers list? You can probably guess a few. America’s Biggest Loser is Washington, D.C., with drivers enjoying an average of 4.8 years between accidents, or about one per presidential administration. That makes District drivers 109.3 percent more likely to get into an accident than the national average. Right next to Washington, D.C., as in real life, is Baltimore, Maryland, with the average driver getting 5.4 years between accidents.
Rounding out the bottom five are Providence, Rhode Island; Hialeah, Florida; and Glendale, California.

There are a few surprises on this list. One is that Reno, Nevada, is the sixth safest city, with an accident frequency 20.2 percent less often than the national average. Meanwhile, Las Vegas is ranked at 130 out of the 200 cities measured, with a 15.2 percent greater accident frequency than the average.
Another is that no cities in Massachusetts were ranked at all because enough information was not available.

A Dubious Second Honor for Fort Collins

But before you people in Fort Collins start feeling superior, it should be noted that the parking department of Old Town Fort Collins was just revealed to be using an AutoVu tracking system that scans, recognizes, and photographs every license plate that passes through the town. The city’s parking department is hanging on to that stash of GPS coordinates and plate numbers for two years—the data was supposed to be tossed out after six months—and anybody who asks for the information can get it. The Coloradoan newspaper got a copy of the database and tracked a reporter’s Jeep to four separate coffee shops and a parking lot, in addition to his apartment. The cars may not be crashing much in that town, but nosy people can find out where they’ve been parked, making Fort Collins a contender for “America’s Safest and Most Spied-Upon Driving City,” perhaps.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text: We recently drove the 2013 Toyota Highlander, and even though we liked it, we thought was room for improvement, especially in interior space.

Cue the redesigned 2014 Highlander. Toyota has tweaked the crossover in a few small but significant ways. The tweaks include revised exterior styling and a redesigned center console (specifically sized to fit a large purse). And remember that tiny third row? It’s been stretched to fit a third passenger.

Whenever I hear that a car has been designed with some feature that’s supposed to appeal specifically to women–like a six-cupholder center console or Honda’s new in-car vacuum–my kneejerk reaction is to dismiss it as pandering.

When I heard that Toyota had specifically engineered the center console in the new Highlander to fit a large purse, I was momentarily annoyed that Toyota thinks women need somewhere to stuff their purses in order to be happy with a car.

Then I thought about how convenient it would be to have a dedicated space to shove my giant bag other than the passenger’s footwell, and I decided this was one piece of gender stereotyping I could get behind.

The purse-concealing center stack is a feature I didn’t even know I was missing in the 2013 Highlander, but the redesigned third-row seat could bump the Highlander up to the short list for buyers who frequently make use of the far back row. The new back row will be more than four inches wider than the outgoing seat, which makes room for a third occupant and means that the Highlander can be configured to seat eight. Larger rear windows also mean that the kids who are relegated to the back seat won’t feel as claustrophobic.
Toyota also redesigned the Highlander’s front fascia with a trapezoidal grille and tweaks to the headlamps and front and rear fenders, which should help the Highlander stand out from the crowd.

Buyers anxious to get their hands on the 2014 Highlander will have to exercise some patience. The gasoline-powered version won’t hit dealerships until this December, with a hybrid model to follow in February of 2014.

Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Key Points

• There are two Varvatos versions of the 2013 Chrysler 300C: Luxury and Limited. They're designed with an industrial look and feel to reflect the Motor City's blue-collar roots.
• In addition to the options listed above, the car we tested has Phantom Black Tri-Coat Pearl exterior paint ($500) on top of the Varvatos Limited Edition package ($3,000), which includes twenty-inch titanium-painted aluminum wheels, leather-trimmed seats, a numbered badge, a special analog clock, black velour floor mats, and satin titanium trim.
• This test car has a black exterior punctuated with metallic finishes inside and out. The cabin features hand-sanded wood, stitching patterned after the designer’s fitted jacket collection, and a special analog clock.
• The Varvatos Limited Edition we drove is not topped out. It can be ordered with optional 363-horsepower 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 engine, which adds an extra $2,200.
• This is one of the most expensive versions of the 300C, and there are several of them, including the Motown Edition, the Glacier Edition, and the 300C SRT8. The SRT8 is the most expensive, with a starting price of $50,445, including $1,000 gas guzzler tax and $995 destination.
• The Chrysler 300 holds a top five-star safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and was a 2013 Top Safety Pick by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. However, IIHS has not conducted small overlap front crash tests on the 2013 Chrysler 300.

• John Varvatos is a menswear designer from Detroit. Women’s Wear Daily praised his fall 2012 collection for its “rock ‘n’ roll vagabond vibe.” His clothes have been described as having a soft, raw, and “lived-in" look.
• Chrysler turned to Varvatos, who has been a celebrity mentor on NBC’s Fashion Star, to extend its “Imported in Detroit” theme that first emerged with Eminem’s gritty Chrysler commercial during the 2011 Super Bowl. That commercial now has more than 16 million YouTube views.
• The Varvatos 300C is another example of when fashion and cars collide. Many designers have linked their names to automobiles. Examples: Victoria Beckham Range Rover Evoque with exclusive matte gray exterior paint and rose gold touches in cabin; Dana Buchman Cadillac SRX with snakeskin print fabric in the storage compartments and silk carpets; Mini Cooper by Kenneth Cole with exterior covered with studs.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Can you believe it? Honda has upped the ante on its generosity toward the American drive-in movie theater. Having already saved five drive-ins by ponying up the more than $75,000 cost of transitioning each theater to digital projection, Honda just announced it will save four more. Considering there are only 357 drive-in theaters left, this ought to make a substantial dent in the closure rate of these American classics.
The four added winners are going to be named on September 23. What are you waiting for? Go to Project Drive-In right now and vote for one of the 116 theaters on that list!

Here's the Back Story

Honda announced its Project Drive-In on August 9. Its aim: to help a few theaters survive after film distributors phase out 35-mm film at the end of this year. Why did Honda do this? Jean asked John Mendel, executive vice-president of automobile sales for American Honda. Here's what he said: ""Drive-In theaters are a unique element of America's car culture and they play heavily in many of our fondest memories." Can't argue with that!

An impressive 121 drive-ins participated in the program, which asked people to vote electronically for their favorite theaters. I promptly loaded up my family to see if the drive-in still has a place in modern society or if perhaps it was time to let them fade away. It was such a great night that I hopped on the soapbox to help save as many theaters as possible. I was especially pulling for the Cherry Bowl in Honor, Michigan (near Traverse City in the northern Lower Peninsula).

For five days in a row, starting on Monday, September 9, Honda announced the five winners. The first winner was the Saco Drive-In in Saco, Maine. I was happy for the lobster-loving Mainelanders, but I was worried for my sweet Cherry Bowl. When on day two Honda announced that the Cherry Bowl had won the second projector, I felt like northern Michigan had really dodged a bullet. The week rolled on with Christmas in September for the 99W in Newberg, Oregon; the Graham in Graham, Texas; and the McHenry in McHenry, Illinois.

We were inspired by the millions of Americans voting to save their local drive-ins and
decided to help even more communities.

All the winners get to show the new movie Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2, ahead of its nationwide opening on September 27, as part of what will surely be a heartfelt community celebration at every theater on that list.

Mendel explained why four more winners are about to be named: "We were inspired by the millions of Americans voting to save their local drive-in theaters and decided to help even more communities ensure that future generations can
enjoy this unique experience."

So thanks, Honda. We haven’t thought about drive-ins much in recent years, and you put them back in the forefront of our minds. You can bet we’ll be spending a few choice evenings up at the Cherry Bowl next summer!

Save the Drive-In! August 22, 2013

pageElements.text: Raise your hand if you love the fake woodie look!
I assume no hands are raised.

The last man standing with fake vinyl exterior panels was the Chrysler PT Cruiser (shown here), and good riddance to that look. Manufacturers have been slower to realize that fake wood on the inside of cars also looks horrible. And then, when they put in real wood but overprocess it until it looks just like plastic, that’s almost worse.
If you are not currently swanning around your neighborhood in a Bentley or a Rolls-Royce, next time you see one, sneak a peek inside and see what real wood looks like.

To Be Real

High-end manufacturers have long understood the need to have authentic materials, and when the sky’s the limit, why would you consider such plebeian choices as pleather or synthetic wood? Fortunately, in recent years many automakers have turned their attention to the wood being used in their interiors. In fact, when I first saw the interior of the 2014 Volvo XC60 (shown at top), I was so impressed with the smooth, matte, totally real-looking wood interior on the center console that I started to dig deeper into exactly what kind of wood Volvo was using in its interiors.

The Wood in the Volvo XC60

The 2014 Volvo XC60’s wood trim looks like a fine piece of furniture rather than the highly glossed wood that has graced some interiors out there. In the past, even when designers have selected real wood, they have made them appear fake with way too much gloss, rather than let the beauty of the wood itself do the shining. This wood actually has a texture to it, and it looked and felt great.

This optional trim from Volvo is  called Urbane Wood. The automaker does not specify the exact tree species that is used but explains that it is real wood—you can tell—sourced from responsibly managed forests and certified by the Forest Steward Council.

Volvo’s spokeswoman, Laura Venezia, went on to explain: “It is constructed from wood that is dyed, and then those different-colored pieces are artfully layered together, creating its intense and distinctive pattern. The pattern was inspired by the exotic grain of the strikingly beautiful but threatened species of African Zebrano.”

Then There’s Lexus

I pushed on to see what other manufacturers were doing with their wood. Lexus is using many different woods and can actually name them, too, but I was most interested in the bamboo they are using in their hybrids. Janis Ambrose Shard is color, material, and finish manager for Lexus, and she explained the division’s choices.

“Our goal is to create a luxurious and comfortable cabin that is consistent with the personality of each Lexus model.  We're often inspired by trends, new processes and innovations.  We look for wood that is distinct and will make our customers feel like they're indulging every time they step in the vehicle. “ Shard also noted that wood selection for Lexus interiors is also, like fish at a fine restaurant, “dependent on market availability."

From the Sublime to the Rare

The fabulous Audi A7 has optional fine grain ash wood in a natural brown color, or layered oak wood interior inlays. It is seriously stunning.

On the other end of the automotive luxury spectrum stands the top-of-the-line Ram Laramie Longhorn pickup truck. Ram has followed the trend of upscale automakers and is using reclaimed wood. Ram’s interior design chief, Ryan Nagode, told the New York Times the fascinating back story of the wood he chose for the Laramie Longhorn: “I wanted it to have the feel of the worn stock of an old shotgun or rifle. I really wanted it to show that it’s real wood.”

So Ram is repurposing distressed wood that it found in Europe, as the Ram Trucks Blog explains. “On French farms, trees are often used as fence posts. Farmers wrap barbed wire around the tree, and over time it grows around the wire. This produces a swirl pattern within the wood. However, not all fence posts are created equal. Only about one in 1,000 trees has the proper pattern to be used in our trucks.”

Let’s Keep It Authentic Out There

I am pleased to see the shift from plastics to real wood, and it is starting to align with my personal artistic vision of real wood. I live in a 100-year-old Victorian home that has unpainted oak trim throughout, so I know what real wood gives to the aesthetic. I am on board —pun intended—with the trend to authentic wood, and I am especially pleased with the move toward reclaimed lumber.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

This car’s price: $23,250 (includes destination)

Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 131 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Safety features: Six airbags, stability control; rearview monitor (part of $950 Technology package)
Tech features: NissanConnect with navigation, Google Send-to-Car, hands-free text messaging assistant (all part of Technology package)
Chief competitor: Ford Transit Connect
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/YxpcKQ6YIpY?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• This is the uplevel model. The base 2013 Nissan NV200 S starts at $20,835, including destination.
• Its only real competitor is the Ford Transit Connect. For 2013, the base Transit Connect XL van starts at $23,420, including destination.
• Fuel economy is comparable to the Ford Transit Connect. The EPA says the Transit Connect returns 21 mpg city/27 mpg highway.
• Our test car was equipped with $1,425 worth of options, including a $190 back door glass package; $190 exterior appearance package that bundles body-colored front and rear bumpers, body-colored door handles, body-colored exterior mirrors, full wheel covers and a chrome grille; $950 technology package that includes a rearview monitor, Bluetooth, Sirius XM Satellite Radio, NissanConnect with navigation, Google Send-to-Car and hands-free text messaging assistant.

• The NV200 is a “box on wheels” or a giant toolbox that is aimed squarely at commercial users, such as caterers, florists, and other small business owners.
• Nissan also collaborated with guitar maker Gibson on an NV200 mobile workshop for guitar repair.
• This vehicle is all about functionality, and it pays to compare it D-ring to D-ring against the Transit Connect. The NV200 has six D-rings in the cargo hold, while the Transit Connect has two.

• The NV200 features unusual 40/60 split rear French doors because Nissan noticed in market research that most people only open one door in the rear. So they figured it was better to make the right side large and the left side smaller so it doesn’t intrude into traffic. The Transit Connect has a 50/50 design.

• Acceleration is slow, and the 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine only delivers 131 horsepower. Plus, this work van is built on the same platform as the Nissan Cube and Versa.
• The NV200 has a small turning circle, which makes it easy to park in urban settings.

• The front passenger's seat in the NV200 folds down to serve as a table for eating or as a workstation.
• The center console can hold hanging file folders, and there’s a drawer under the passenger's seat. There's also a cubby for a tablet.
• The NV200 has flat wheel intrusions in the cabin, while the TC’s are rounded and intrude into the space.

• In addition to the basic NV200 cargo van and the NV200 taxi, there is an NV passenger van, which seats up to twelve, and the new NV200 compact cargo van, aimed at business owners who can get by with a smaller vehicle.
• By the way, Ford just rolled out the new 2014 Transit Connect Taxi in late September. This is war!

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There’s something that feels uniquely American about taking a long cross-country road trip. It’s on every car-loving teenager’s to-do list, just as soon as they can shake off the oppressive parental yoke and do it on their own. The quintessential Americanness of the transcontinental journey hasn’t stopped British-born, German-owned Mini from getting in on the game, though.

The quirky car company runs a biannual two-week rally that takes thousands of Mini owners and enthusiasts on a road trip across the Lower Forty-Eight. It’s nearly a year away, but Mini is already planning for the fifth Mini Takes the States event next summer, which will lead drivers from San Francisco all the way to Boston.

Thinking of Joining Up?

The trip will start on July 26, 2014, and stop in fourteen cities on the way to its arrival in Boston on August 9. The route reaches as far south as Austin, Texas, and as far north as Buffalo, New York. (Last time, in 2012, the route went from east to west.) Mini expects thousands of Mini owners to join the caravan for all or part of the journey, which meanders through seventeen states. That's right: You can jump in (and out) along the way if you can't mark off that entire block of time next summer.

These offbeat yet ambitious events are just part of doing business with Mini. The brand prides itself in its goofy, enthusiastic attitude and encourages its drivers to participate in Mini rallies whenever possible. This spring, for example, nearly 900 Minis paraded across Michigan’s Mackinac Bridge, the longest suspension bridge in the Western Hemisphere, in an attempt to break a Guinness record for the longest parade of Minis. Although unsuccessful in that quest, the group did manage to set a record for the largest ensemble of car horns, an accomplishment any motorist would be proud of.
If spending two weeks driving cross-country in a Mini sounds like your kind of party, sign up to receive e-mail updates from Mini.

title: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In
promoTitle: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In
promoTeaserSmall: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety crown one harness brand that can keep your dog safer in the car.
promoTeaser: Subaru and Center for Pet Safety crown one harness brand that can keep your dog safer in the car.
metaTitle: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In
metaDescription: Dog Restraint Test Results Are In: Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety, after testing, name one brand of harness that can keep your pet safer in the car. Find out which one at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Center for Pet Safety, under Subaru sponsorship, has announced the results of its comprehensive safety testing of dog harnesses for use in the car. The 2013 Dynamic Testing Harness Study crowned one top tether: the Sleepypod Clickit Utility Harness. This three-point harness for pets in the car won the Top Performing Harness title for 2013. Subaru said in a press release that it intends to start offering this harness as an accessory through its Subaru Gear catalog in the near future.
To win that distinction, the Sleepypod product passed rigorous crash testing at an independent lab that also does testing for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Amazingly enough, there are currently no performance standards in place for products aiding the safety of pets riding in the car. Somehow, the stringent regulations for carrying babies and children in the car have not trickled down to apply to dogs. That's where the Center for Pet Safety and Subaru stepped in. This testing was looking to see if the crash test dummy dogs shown here, including a twenty-five-pound terrier mix, a forty-five-pound border collie, and a seventy-five-pound golden retriever, could safely ride in the car using commercially available safety harnesses. Jean Knows Cars talked to Lindsey Wolko of the Center for Pet Safety on Wednesday about the results of those tests.

As you might have seen from our videos here and here, we are strong advocates of restraining pets inside the car. It only makes sense for the safety and comfort of both your dogs and the people who ride with them. The Center for Pet Safety's 2011 pilot study showed that none of the commercially available harnesses at that time tested out as safe.

Pets Must Not Be on Too Long a Tether

The major problem: the stuffed dog used as a test dummy is launched right off the seat in a crash. Not safe for the dog, of course, but also potentially very dangerous for human passengers who could be hit by a flying pet. The problem is that dogs are literally on too long a leash: extensions that don't tie the pet securely enough into the car also risk injury.

Lindsey Wolko of the Center for Pet Safety reflected on the previous tests and the results of this summer's testing. "If you look at those original tests, we have a very clear understanding of what the products could not do.

"What pet owners have been told all these years is that they can put their dog in the car using long extensions [on harnesses or leashes] that give the dog a lot of freedom. That's very dangerous. We need to re-educate that people need to rein in their pets.
"We do know that having an adjustable tether and getting it as short as possible is going to provide a better outcome," Wolko said.

This Summer's Tests and What They Measured

In the new tests, Wolko said, products were downgraded for "catastrophic failure," if they allowed the dog to launch off the seat, or if the tether could not be shortened to six inches or less. A summary of test results, plus a full list of the brands tested, is viewable on the website of the Center for Pet Safety.

The Center's testing included eleven brands that claimed the status of a safety product. The products included the AllSafe, Bergan, Canine Friendly, Champion, Clix, EZ-Rider, PetBuckle, Ruff Rider Roadie, Snoozer, and Tru-Fit harnesses in addition to the winning Sleepypod Clickit Utility. After initial testing, seven products graduated to crash testing. Wolko noted that the manufacturers were all invited to come watch the testing, and all of them came.

"We're primarily a consumer advocacy organization, and this is something very important for consumers," Wolko told Jean Knows Cars on Wednesday. "We collected baseline data, and we're in the process of writing the standard now." Wolko said the organization is seeking out people who are "noted auto safety specialists" to review the data, and more information about that process will be released soon.
The Center for Pet Safety intends to pursue a certification process for pet safety products inside the car, but that's "down the road," Wolko told us.
In the meantime, we'll be getting some of those Sleepypod harnesses and checking them out for our own pets.

pageElements.text:
THE MOVING ASSEMBLY LINE TURNS 100 TODAY!

Can an invention celebrate a birthday? Yes, and every person on the planet who uses manufactured goods should send a birthday card to the Moving Assembly Line that Henry Ford introduced on October 7, 1913. I am a firm believer in the assembly-line approach to pretty much everything. When I fold the laundry I fold all the T-shirts at once, and then pants, socks, underwear, etc.—it just makes sense.

In 1912, The Ford Motor Company produced 82,388 Model Ts, and the basic Touring model sold for $600. Ford set out to streamline the process so that the selling price could be reduced to a level where the rising middle class could purchase his products.

For Downton Abbey fans, this was all happening at the same time Mary had her tryst with the Turkish attaché Kemal Pamuk, and of course on the other side of the pond. Just putting things in perspective.

Anyway, on this day in 1913, Ford set up a 150-foot assembly line at his Highland Park, Michigan, assembly plant. There, 140 assemblers were stationed along the line to install parts on a chassis that engineers had constructed using a winch and a rope. From this crude beginning, the process quickly evolved. The following year, the rope was replaced by an endless chain. The time it took to produce one vehicle was reduced by over nine hours to fewer than three. Ford had created a win-win: he got filthy rich, and the middle class got to drive cars.
 
The idea of moving the product to the worker rather than the worker to the product was revolutionary, and it helped smooth out the pacing of production. By 1916, the number of Model Ts produced reached 585,388, but the big news was the price had been significantly reduced. The Touring model now sold for only $360. According to an inflation calculator, that would equate to roughly $8,500 today. I would love to buy a new car for that price.

The modern assembly line has greatly changed from 1913, but the premise of streamlining the process prevails. The auto plants of today have taken significant strides thanks to the Toyota Production Systems, but the backbone still harks back to Oct 7, 1913. So, hats off to Henry Ford and his good ol' American ingenuity.

title: 2014 Chevrolet Malibu LT
promoTeaserSmall: I could be good friends with this car. It wouldn't be a passionate affair, but that might be OK.
promoTeaser: I could be good friends with this car. It wouldn't be a passionate affair, but that might be OK.
metaTitle: 2014 Chevrolet Malibu - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Malibu: Should you buy this car? Laura and Molly tried it out on the country roads of Southeast Michigan, and here's their verdict. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $26,835 as tested (turbo model: $35,105 as tested) (prices include destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 196 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Stop/start technology
Option I can’t live without: Siri Eyes Free for use with iPhone
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Jetta
See more specs on the Chevrolet Malibu lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Niche cars are fun. Minicars are cute and funny, high-end sports cars are thrilling and attitudinal, and big utility vehicles are inspiring, challenging, and sometimes refreshingly weird. This is not a story about any of those. This is a story about the 2014 Chevrolet Malibu, the nice guy among cars: worthy of being appreciated for what it is. Why hold it up against more glamorous cars and say it doesn’t measure up?

Yes, the Malibu is the fourth runner-up this year in the sales contest in that most mainstream category of all, the mid-size sedan. In 2013 so far, the Malibu, despite being all new for the model year, has sold less than half as many copies as the leader, the Toyota Camry.
It’s for that reason that Chevrolet took that all-new model and redid it.

This story could sound discouraging for the Malibu, but the fact is that the car is actually improved in a few important ways, and the other fact is that senior editor Molly Jean and I enjoyed driving it around the countryside.
The 2014 Malibu has two interesting changes: stop/start technology and Text-to-Voice.

Stop/start technology is a fuel saver that has generally been found on more high-end vehicles, and the Malibu is the first in this segment to have this feature as standard. Basically, it works by having the engine shut off automatically when the car comes to a stop, for example at a light. It’s designed to be simple and seamless, and when we drove the Malibu through the small downtown of suburban Northville, we enjoyed waiting for it to kick in at stoplights and then listening to hear the engine resume when the light turned green. It would be a good feeling as the owner of this car to know you were saving gas while idling at intersections.

But let’s talk about that hands-free texting feature. Chevrolet is to be applauded for putting it on this mainstream car to help reduce the prevalence of cell-phone-in-ear syndrome on the roads. To take best advantage of the system, you should have an iPhone, because you can get the 2014 Malibu with Siri Eyes Free. Basically, it turns itself into a giant iPhone 4S or 5 by providing voice-controlled connectivity. I couldn’t wait to try it, and immediately on climbing in to the Malibu SE, I inserted my iPhone 4S into the perfectly sized slot in the center console, pressed the Bluetooth control, and gave it a try.

The Chevrolet version of Siri was a woman with a voice just a little different from that of the original. Molly and I tried out the Siri Eyes Free setup on Jean, calling her cell phone and taking turns shouting out our conversation through the Chevrolet MyLink system. Text-to-Voice converts text messages to speech and reads them aloud to you. The system also lets you send one of a number of text messages via voice commands, either stock ones ("I’m driving and can’t talk right now") or custom ones you create (“Is your homework done? Is your homework done? Is your homework done?” is one I’d set up and use a lot).

There are two engines available for the 2014 Malibu. There’s a new 2.5-liter four-cylinder Ecotec engine that makes 196 horsepower, teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission that’s new to the Malibu this year. Malibu chief engineer Todd Pawlik says Chevrolet expects 85 to 90 percent of buyers to choose this engine. Its fuel economy of 25 mpg in town and 36 mpg on the highway is comparable, for example, to the 26/34 mpg of the competitor Ford Fusion with the 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine.

The other engine is a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder that makes 259 horsepower and 295 pound-feet of torque. That torque is what gives the turbo engine its “oomph,” which we enjoyed while out on straight, deserted farmland roads. But honestly, for the way we would normally drive a mid-size sedan, I could see choosing the more fuel-efficient normally aspirated engine.

Chevrolet made a big deal out of the added 1.25 inches of legroom in the back seat for 2014. Apparently, people complained that it was too tight back there. And I can understand that complaint, because if you wanted a cramped back seat, you would buy a compact car, not a mid-size sedan. The back seat in the 2014 Malibu seemed adequate; the front seats have been reshaped to be more concave to accommodate the knees of your rear-seat passengers. There is a fold-down center console for times when you have two passengers, not three, back there.

As for interior amenities, Molly and I strongly disliked the shiny fake wood in an odd grayish hue. But the Chevrolet MyLink was a pleasure to use, as always: intuitive, clear, and simple. As a bonus, the screen flips open, secret agent style, to reveal a secret compartment big enough to hide your iPod or wallet...or that Snickers bar you are going to eat when the kids get out of the car at school.

Here's the thing about the Malibu: it's never going to be an exciting car. Nobody ever fell asleep at night dreaming about someday getting to drive one. But as your mother told you (and I tell my kids), there's a whole lot going on in life besides that. There's a different kind of excitement that comes from knowing you have a reliable, economical straight shooter of a car out in the driveway that will take you, your kids, and your stuff through the carpool and down to the Brownie meeting without drama.
Make fun of fleet-style cars all you want; they're (as that old commercial used to say) the heartbeat of America.

The Verdict:

Are you looking for a mid-size sedan? There are so many competitors, from the sleek and attractive Ford Fusion to the reliable standard Toyota Camry and Honda Accord to the quirkier Volkswagen Jetta. The Chevrolet Malibu has not stood out against that backdrop, and I'm not sure it does now, but that doesn't mean there's nothing to like about it. The stop/start technology, the voice to text, and the general user-friendliness of this car might be just what you're looking for. If so, you won't be swept off your feet, but that's not to say it might not be the beginning of a beautiful friendship for you and your family.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Malibu is in the uber-competitive family sedan segment, and this segment is in my opinion is also uber-bland. That being said, the Malibu is a perfectly fine-looking car, both inside and out. I was a little offended by the fake gray wood, but not too much. An awful lot of engineering has gone into the start/stop technology to help eke out better mpg numbers, and it is indeed a seamless movement. However, if you would like a turbo that also gets truly great mpg, you should consider the Volkswagen Passat TDI instead. The Malibu's turbo delivered instant acceleration but failed to give an exciting driving experience.

As I drove it, I repeatedly thought that the Malibu would be a perfect car for my husband—sensible, inexpensive, and not showy. I would recommend this car for someone who believes a car has one purpose: to shuttle people efficiently and have creature comforts that make the experience pleasant. It will not excite, but will suffice.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: I’m a sucker for a good road trip, so when my cousin Ellen told me she was planning a move to Washington, D.C., about a month ago, I immediately hopped on board and told her I’d drive. I was looking forward to a weekend escape from Michigan’s fall chill and perhaps a visit to the zoo, my favorite destination in any city.

What better vehicle than a Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec for our drive? I’d driven the diesel burner once before and wanted to see how it well my opinion of it would hold up on a long drive. I was also interested to see what Ellen, who isn’t exactly a car fiend, would think of driving a diesel-powered car.

The GLK250 BlueTec starts at $39,495 after destination, but the one that showed up in my driveway tipped the scales at $50,485. Our options included the $3,450 Premium package, which added auto-dimming mirrors, a power liftgate, SiriusXM radio, and an MP3 media interface, so you can hook your iPod directly up to the stereo. Another $2,790 got us a navigation system, a rearview camera, and a six-disc CD changer.

The standard MB-Tex (Mercedes-Benz code for “not leather”) seats were comfortable and attractive enough to make you think twice before springing for the $1,850 leather seating package. Also standard are 4Matic all-wheel drive, LED running lights, and Mercedes-Benz’s Attention Assist technology.

The GLK’s cargo area would have been more than large enough for two or even four people with just a weekend’s worth of luggage each, but since we were carrying a bit of a heavier load, we had to fold the rear seats down to preserve a clear view through the rear window. With a cooler full of sandwiches and cookies in the back, we were ready to ride.

Mercedes-Benz representatives often joke that if you take one of their diesel cars on a road trip, you’ll need to stop for a bathroom break before you need to stop for fuel. Indeed, when we made our first pit stop after nearly three hours of driving, the GLK250’s tank was still three-quarters full. The GLK250 BlueTec is rated at 33 mpg on the highway, but I had averaged more than 35 mpg, even while driving closer to 80 mph than 70.

When we stopped for dinner, we had just over a quarter of a tank of fuel and about 100 miles of driving left. I was confident that we would make it to Washington with room to spare, and I was right. With two miles to go to our destination, the low-fuel light came on, indicating that the car had a comfortable sixty miles of range left. We had averaged 35.6 mpg, more than two mpg over the GLK250’s highway EPA rating.

When I got back behind the driver’s seat on Sunday morning for my solo return trip, I was a little concerned that I would have a hard time finding diesel fuel in Washington, D.C. I needn’t have worried. The navigation system’s POI database had a special category for gas stations with diesel fuel. The fillup cost nearly $60, which seems like a lot until you consider that was all the fuel I’d needed to travel across four states. When I got back in the car, the trip calculator indicated that I had almost 600 miles of range, roughly twice the range of my personal car.

The GLK was just about everything you want from a road trip car. It’s attractive, it’s comfortable, it’s fuel-efficient, it’s quiet. Our only real complaints were that the GLK would struggle to comfortably accommodate rear passengers on a long drive, and that the navigation system’s voice guidance was essentially inaudible.

Mercedes-Benz has done an admirable thing with the GLK250 BlueTec: the company has  managed to create an alternative-fuel vehicle that you’ll forget is different. Until you realize you’re driving by all those gas stations you used to stop at.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first thing my husband did when I bought him his very first computer, the original Apple iMac in the translucent turquoise case, was click on the bookmarks I created for him to make him interested in it. One was the Chesapeake Bay Retriever Club. And he bought a dog. Because he only had one, his boon companion RonDog, and he wanted Ron to have a playmate.

He got an address for the breeder in Illinois, and off we went on a late November day. I expected a four-hour drive, but as it turned out, it was on the Missouri border, so we ended up spending the night. The breeder had her puppies in the barn. There was only one girl, and that's what we wanted, so we swept her up into our arms, handed over the money, and got a hotel room.

The first thing she did when we set her on the bed was pee on it. I grabbed her up in mid-pee and got her outside, and that may be the only time she ever peed inside again. She has always been the sweetest, nicest, loveliest little dog we have ever had.

Our first Chesapeake Bay retriever, Ron, died at age thirteen, a few months after we brought our fourth Chessie, Bob, home. Bob had kept him going quite a few months, but he finally passed on. We didn't really expect how hard Louie would take it. She moped around for about a month, but she immediately took his spot on the little Persian rug by the door and his place of honor under the table at mealtime.

For the past three years, she has been the grande dame of the house. She sits quietly, like a sphinx, and the boy dogs have learned not to mess with her. You don't take her toy; you don't smell her butt; you don't touch her. She's like a Live and Let Live kind of dog, but when she gets ticked off, it sounds like a horrible dog fight, but it's over in a second, and Louie is sitting proudly in her place while the other dog has already slunk off to the other room. She has never started a fight, but she's finished every one that ever got started with her.
For the past three years, she has been the grande dame of the house. She sits quietly, like a sphinx, and the boy dogs have learned not to mess with her.

She was a genetic mess with a lower jaw that never grew and two rear knees that needed to be rebuilt before she was a year old, but it never seemed to slow her down, until this year. She can still hear the sound of the plastic lid being peeled off the dog treat box from two rooms away, and every now and then, when she's tired of lying on her dog bed, she'll hurl herself up into the middle of our king-size bed, where she'll lie proudly all afternoon in the sun.

Louie runs for a treat with her rear legs slid out from under her as she goes around the turn from the sitting room to the dining room, and my heart just leaps in my throat. She's as sharp as she ever was, happy as a lark. She's just having a hard time with those back legs. I absolutely refuse to put down a dog who is so bright and so happy, just because she can't stand for very long. We're investigating acupuncture right now, and by God, if I have to I'll build her a little cart.

Both Tim and I have put down many dogs. It doesn't get any easier, that's for sure. We were talking about it once to our friend who married us, the late Judge George Alexander, and he said, "The reason that dogs don't live longer than they do is so we have an opportunity to know so many good ones." Right now, I just want to know the ones I have. Happy birthday, my little bat-eared dog!

title: 2013 Dodge Avenger SXT
promoTeaserSmall: It's got an old-school vibe; James Garner would go for it. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: It's got an old-school vibe; James Garner would go for it. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Avenger SXT - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Dodge Avenger SXT: I appreciate those leather jacket looks paired with modern safety and fuel economy. But what does the Peanut Gallery think? Read our review and find out if you should buy it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $23,195 base, $25,380 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 283 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Option I can’t live without: Blacktop appearance package ($495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Malibu, Chrysler 200, Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry
See more specs on the Dodge Avenger lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

The best comments I heard about the Dodge Avenger while driving it came from hard-working solid citizens of commerce. At the McDonald’s drive-through, in the Target parking lot, places like that, I would hear: “Wow, I love your car. Coolest ever!” That was my first hint that the Avenger’s look appealed to somebody, because at first glance, it sure didn’t appeal to me.

It’s not that the black-on-black look doesn’t suit me; that’s pretty much the look I wear myself on a daily basis. It’s not that it’s ugly; it’s actually quite attractive in a retro kind of way. The Avenger was not my favorite look simply because it doesn’t seem quite modern. It wouldn’t have seemed out of place in a 1970s TV detective drama, perhaps driven by one of the bad guys. If he were still working out of Malibu, TV’s Jim Rockford might have driven this instead of the Pontiac Firebird he used to park outside the trailer. That’s not a slur on the Avenger: this is a solidly well-priced car that stands out from the modern pack of mid-size sedans specifically because it does look so old school and timeless.

What can you buy for under $25,000 that doesn’t look entry level? This car. Although it looks like a grownup’s car, it still starts at an entry-level-worthy $20,890 for the base model. That one comes with a 173-horsepower four-cylinder and a four-speed automatic transmission, which you can swap for a six-speed automatic for an extra $200.

But you can get something a little more interesting, like the car you see in these photos, without spending a whole lot more. Chrysler brags that it's "America's most powerful and affordable V-6 mid-size car." Opting up to the midrange SXT we tested, with its six-speed automatic transmission and 3.6-liter Pentastar V-6 with variable valve timing and 283 horsepower, only increases the price to $25,380. That price includes $300 extra for the V-6, plus the Chrysler UConnect telematics package ($995), which adds the very modern Bluetooth voice-command connectivity, GPS navigation, and a 6.5-inch touchscreen.

It also includes the indispensable Blacktop package ($495), which toughens up the look of the Avenger with eighteen-inch gloss black wheels, gloss black grille, black headlamp covers and a body-color spoiler. You can get the Blacktop package with other body colors—Redline Pearl, Bright White, and Granite Crystal or Billet Silver metallic—but the black-on-black look is hard to argue against. The black-on-black Avenger is the car equivalent of a black leather motorcycle jacket, and it should appeal to the same people who appreciate that look.

Once inside, the Avenger is surprisingly comfortable and well constructed, especially for its price. I am a big fan of the supportive, comfortable leather seating in this SXT, and I can’t say enough good things about Dodge’s large, solid, satisfying-to-turn knobs on the instrument panel. Our SXT had heated front seats as part of the $400 leather seat package.

This doesn’t look like a family car on the outside, and it’s not quite a family car inside. Its back seat would be best for two passengers with the center console folded down, as legroom is somewhat limited back there. If you’re not going to carry more than four on a regular basis, it would not be an issue.

Driving the Avenger was not indistinguishable from driving almost any V-6-powered sedan. There was more than enough easily accessible power, and it was capable and competent over a variety of road surfaces, while smooth and comfortable to drive around town. I wouldn’t go as far as to call it exciting; it’s a mid-size sedan after all. But I think it could stand next to any of the cars in its category for ride and for a solid driving experience. I not only enjoyed running errands in it; I felt a little like Stealth Mom, conventional on the inside but black leather on the outside. It was a whole different persona than I'd have inside a Honda Accord or a Toyota Camry, and it could grow on me.

The Verdict:

If you are looking for a mid-size sedan but are just a little bored by the common favorites like the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, and Nissan Altima, go a little farther afield and check out the Dodge Avenger. You’re less likely to see one around every corner. Despite the comic-book name, the Avenger has decent fuel economy at 19 mpg city and 29 mpg highway, even with that 283-hp V-6 under the hood. It’s even a Top Safety Pick + from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, so it’s a more mature and modern sedan choice than you might think by looking at it.

Who's going to buy this car? It is priced very well for a young working-class striver to afford, but it's not necessarily a car that a younger person might go for. Comfortable, fuel-efficient, solid-looking, old school: I'm seeing a hard-working person on my side of forty, but one who is still interested in staying out late on a Saturday night. She might be asking herself, What would James Garner drive? And this might be the answer.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: I'm not a big fan of the Avenger's exterior styling, and even though the interior is comfortable and well appointed and our test car's V-6 engine puts out almost 300 horsepower, I still can't see myself picking this car over its (more attractive) competition.

Molly Jean: I think Dodge is missing its target audience by marketing the Avenger to customers who want an enthusiastic driving experience. This car is perfect for the older driver who is not technologically savvy. Three fifty-cent-piece size buttons control the climate control, and the UConnect system is very user-friendly. In fact, the entire car is very utilitarian and would appeal to a cost-conscious buyer who desires efficiency over modern design. To really seal the deal in the older-customer niche, Dodge will need to add a retirement beige exterior that can be completed with the already available frost interior.
