pageElements.text: Every parent of a teen understands the simultaneous convenience and terror that comes with the acquisition of a learner’s permit. Another willing driver in the family? Fantastic. The fact that teens have the highest crash rate of any group in the United States? Terrifying. It’s almost a natural parental reaction to hold on to the keys or restrict a teen’s opportunity to drive and only let him or her drive in places that feel safe to you. AAA says there is something more you can do. Parents can improve their teen’s driving—and thus their odds—by coaching them to take on more challenging driving conditions.
We see gaps between parents’ understanding of what they should be doing and what they are actually doing in the car.

“We see gaps between parents’ understanding of what they should be doing and what they are actually doing in the car,” explains Justin McNaull, director of state relations for AAA. Nearly half of parents reported they wanted their teens to get “a lot of practice,” when asked about their plans for their teens’ driving. Yet only about one in four parents mentioned practicing under a variety of situations or conditions, such as in bad weather, in heavy traffic, or on unfamiliar roads. That's one reason why the auto safety association has come up with teaching aids for parents. They're a good deal anytime, but this week only, they are on sale here.

Five Ways You Can Help Your Teenager

This brief moment when your teen driver is under your supervision is an opportunity to convey some of your hard-earned road experience. It’s easy to forget how long it took you to acquire those driving skills you’ve accumulated over many years of experience. But those higher-order driving skills you picked up can be taught, too. Here are five ways you can mentor your teenage driver.

1. Take a minute when your teen first gets a permit to think about all the places in town you don’t like to drive—that scary traffic circle, the freeway on-ramp, a particularly confusing intersection—and come up with an inventory of challenging places and conditions.

2. Using the list, create an informal syllabus that will bring your teenage driver up to speed on the whole menu of traffic and road types. Start your teen off with simple roads and ideal conditions. Then gradually add traffic, poor weather, darkness, freeways, rural two-lane highways, gravel roads, tunnels, and traffic circles. “Your teen is going to end up driving in those places eventually,” says McNaull. Why not make her first experience a controlled one with you there to offer advice and suggestions? “Start working your way through that list,” says McNaull. “You don’t have to do all of it in the first month of driving.”

3. Make sure both you and your teenager go through a major attitude check before you get into the car together. Agree that you will both remain calm, patient, and positive, will listen to each other, and will take regular breaks to talk about how it’s going. Make sure you and your teenager both give feedback to each other about the driving experience as it happens, so that time together is learning time. AAA calls this “commentary driving.”

4. Brush up on your driving knowledge and pass along your own advice to new drivers by entering the AAA “Are You Smarter Than Your Teen Driver?” contest. It’s quite possible that some things have changed since you learned to drive, and this quiz will help you review how basic driving recommendations have changed (such as the hand position on the steering wheel). It’s set up like a contest, with a winner to be named in December.

4. Consider taking AAA’s online parent involvement course. The parent coach is considered such an important part of learning to drive that Connecticut and Massachusetts even require parents to enroll in a parent involvement session so they can learn to be better coaches. AAA’s online version is available to everybody, with some videos and resources free on the site—like this brochure, and a full DVD course and manual for $29.95.

Sale Alert!

Through October 26, AAA is discounting Driver-ZED, an interactive computer program that uses live-action video and 100 scenarios to teach risk management behind the wheel. It's available for only $7 using the coupon code “TeenZED.” Teaching Your Teens to Drive is offered for $12.95. A bargain at twice the price, if you have teenage drivers in your life now or will have in the near future.

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s not exactly a secret that we’re pro-diesel here at Jean Knows Cars. Jean owns (and loves) a Volkswagen Jetta Sportwagen TDI. I drove a Mercedes-Benz GLK250 BlueTec twice and loved it both times.

Why should you love diesels, too? Diesel vehicles can earn significantly higher fuel economy than their gasoline counterparts, and new technology means these cars are no longer loud or smelly. But even though today’s diesels are virtually indistinguishable from gasoline-powered cars and even though diesel engines are available in everything from sport sedans to full-size pickups, they’re still not the first thing that comes to mind when you think “luxury.”
Or are they? Enter Audi's TDI lineup.

Oysters, Champagne, Diesel Fuel

Starting with the 2014 model year, Audi is now offering diesel versions of its A6, A7, A8, Q5, and Q7 models. Previously, only the Q7 and A8 were available as diesel models. We had the pleasure of welcoming a 2014 Audi A7 TDI and Q5 TDI to our offices in the past few weeks, and we found that, in the case of these two, luxury and diesel go together like oysters and champagne. Audi’s TDIs command a premium over gasoline-powered versions of the same car, but they also earn significantly better mpg ratings. Our A7 TDI with its 3.0-liter, 240-hp V-6 engine is rated at 38 mpg on the highway. An A7 with the 3.0-liter, 310-hp supercharged gasoline-powered engine is rated at just 28 mpg highway. The Q5 TDI ekes 31 highway mpg out of the same 3.0-liter diesel engine; that's 5 mpg more than a Q5 with a 3.0-liter gasoline engine.

With an as-tested price of $81,395, it’s safe to say that few of the people who buy an A7 TDI are interested in the money they will save on fuel. The more modest (but similarly equipped) Q5 TDI we tested still commanded a $55,445 asking price, and even a Q5 TDI with no options costs upward of $10,000 more than the base-model Q5. Both vehicles came standard with sumptuous black leather interiors and the Audi MMI infotainment system, and both sported the optional S line exterior styling. The turbo-diesel engine pumps out a smallish 240 horsepower, but with an impressive 428 pound-feet of torque you won’t lose many stoplight races.

Spending time behind the wheel of either of these cars is enough to turn you into a diesel convert. The all-black leather interior is as sleek and stylish as the cars’ modern exteriors and should impress even the most jaded passengers. Audi’s MMI infotainment system is simple and intuitive to use. Both cars are plenty powerful and capable, and when you’re driving them they feel exactly right: comfortable, responsive, attractive, engaging. They also have the advantage of conferring a certain status upon the driver. They say: “This person can spend twice the average annual salary on their automobile.” It’s the kind of thing we all hope our cars might say about us one day, although most of us will never be able to afford it.

That’s perhaps the biggest problem with Audi’s TDIs: it takes serious mental gymnastics to convince yourself that they’re worth the multi-thousand-dollar premium. The EPA estimates that the A7 TDI will save drivers $1,500 in fuel over five years, compared with the average new vehicle, while owners of a Q5 TDI will save $750. If buyers are contemplating one of Audi’s TDIs instead of something significantly more affordable, they’ll probably get tired of the car before they realize much fuel savings, making their TDI purchase essentially a very expensive way to achieve longer range between fill-ups.

But that all changes if you are planning to buy an Audi anyway. The gasoline-powered A7 is significantly less fuel-efficient than the average new vehicle, causing drivers to spend $2,250 more in fuel over a five-year period than the TDI version, which is right at the average mark. The same goes for the Q5. The gasoline-powered 3.0-liter V-6 version will cost you $2,250 more than the average in fuel over five years; the TDI will save you $750 off the average cost over five years.

At the end of the day, it’s unlikely that drivers of the A7 TDI or Q5 TDI will choose their car because it makes financial sense. Drivers will choose these cars because they make a statement, because of their excellence, and because their impressive gas mileage will allow roughly 500 miles between trips to the pump. After spending some time with both cars, I can’t say I’d argue with them.

2014 Audi A7 TDI Quattro Tiptronic

Price: $81,395 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.0-liter turbo-diesel V-6, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed Tiptronic automatic with Audi quattro all-wheel drive
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Black leather interior
Option I can’t live without: S line exterior appearance package
You might also be considering: BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class, Porsche Panamera

2014 Audi Q5 TDI Quattro Tiptronic

Price: $55,445 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.0-liter turbo-diesel V-6, 240 horsepower, 428 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Eight-speed Tiptronic automatic with Audi quattro all-wheel drive
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Black leather interior
Option I can’t live without: S line plus exterior appearance package
You might also be considering: Acura RDX, BMW X3, Lexus RX, Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I made a whirlwind tour of Southern California last weekend. It began with collecting a 2014 Soul Red Metallic Mazda CX-5 at Wally Park. Does Wally Park know how stupid that name is? A wally is a stupid person, and I felt stupid climbing on the Wally bus. No offense to the Wallys out there, of course. I don’t believe there are any in my extended family. Hold those calls and letters; I’ll make it up to you in the Christmas letter.

As soon as I climbed into the CX-5, I felt a lot better. I fact, as soon as I saw my lovely compact sport-ute, I felt a lot better. The CX-5 was exactly what I needed to travel the hundreds, and I mean hundreds, of congested miles I was about to drive. The first thing I did was connect my phone, which happened in a second and which completely downloaded my phone list and all my music. But during the whole weekend, I couldn’t figure out how to make the music stop while phone calls were coming in, without reading the owner’s manual, which didn’t happen to be in the glove box. I tried turning the volume way down, but that also turned down the volume of the caller. It finally occurred to me to unhook the iPhone cord from the CX-5 and use the phone on Bluetooth.

I started with meetings in Irvine, so I had to go south from LAX, on to San Clemente, back up to downtown L.A. the following morning, back down to San Clemente, south to San Diego, back to downtown L.A., back to San Clemente, and finally back to LAX.

The first thing I did was head south to Irvine to meet with our great Jean Knows Cars team who built and maintain our website. It’s always fun to be with those people. We went to some Brazilian steakhouse, where an endless procession of guys with swords full of meat come to your table. It was the most meat I’d eaten in about a year. It was a blast, and we spent the whole time talking about our big plans for the rest of the year.

I stayed with friends in San Clemente and didn’t need to get back up to L.A. until lunch on Friday. When I got up in the morning and told my friends what time I needed to be there for lunch, they looked stricken and said, “You need to leave right now.” It was 8:30 a.m., leaving me a paltry three hours to drive sixty miles. “It’s going to be even worse trying to get back here in the afternoon,” they said. Driving here is reason enough to just hate L.A. You never know if it will take forty minutes to go thirty miles, or two hours. I ran for the CX-5, plugged in the downtown address, and…

… discovered the most incredible nav system I have ever experienced. This was not what I was expecting, because the previous CX-5 had one of the worst nav systems ever. The new system is powered by TomTom with IQ Routes™ technology, and it’s part of the Grand Touring Tech package ($1,625) that also includes HID headlamps, adaptive front lighting, keyless entry, and smart city brake support. But let’s just focus on this nav system, because it is life altering.

It’s not one of the biggest screens at 5.8 inches, but it’s a responsive touchscreen, and the display is very crisp. It has a lot of information, and the information is very easy to read, with type and icons as big as they can possibly be. Every time you need to change direction, the arrow takes up most of the screen, so you can tell right away if you need to be left or right, or for upcoming turns, so you can position yourself in the lane early at a glance. There’s a lot of other information on the screen that is easy to access once you get used to it.

Most important of all, this system, IQ Routes, displays a spinning number of how many roads it’s analyzing. At one point, I saw that over 200,000 roads were being scanned for my route to downtown L.A. At first I thought it was a cool party trick, but during the course of driving in stop-and-go traffic, three different times, the system announced the delay in real time. Every time it registered a delay in my route on its software, it made an announcement: “Your traffic delay is now nine minutes. You are still on the fastest route,” or, “Your traffic delay is now twenty-six minutes. There is a new route that will save you twenty-two minutes. Do you want to take it?” and then you hit the button for Yes or No. It also asks you whether you want to use the carpool lane and toll roads. Once you answer these questions, it immediately reroutes you. The last rerouting it made took me off the stopped freeway and put me on surface streets past scrapyards and down some streets that were pretty sketchy, other than the fact that there was absolutely zero traffic on any of them. I arrived at my lunch appointment thirty minutes early. At one point I was going to be nine minutes late, so the reroute saved a total of thirty-nine minutes.

I immediately put all of my faith in the CX-5’s nav. Just knowing that you are "still on the fastest route" sort of takes the worry out of driving in L.A. It’s too bad there isn’t a system like that for buying a car, so you know throughout the negotiations that you are “still getting the best deal.”

My advice is, if you live in L.A., you need to buy this nav system no matter what car is wrapped around it. My review of the car is almost immaterial. Yeah, the CX-5 is really cute. It works really well. It has a lot of space. But OMG, that nav system. IQ indeed.

The next day, I had to go up to El Segundo for some corporate meetings, which left me stuck in the usual snarl of traffic heading south out of L.A. on Friday night. (I saved eight minutes on a reroute through Long Beach.) But I was finally aimed toward the weekend as I joined the traffic basically stopped on the 405. I was looking forward to staying with friends in San Clemente. I not only borrowed this CX-5 from Mazda, I was staying with a Mazda PR executive and his wife the whole weekend. When I pulled up, there were two CX-5s in his driveway: one was his wife’s, and one belonged to another journalist who was visiting.

Every year my friends have a magnificent Halloween costume party attended by people deadly serious about winning the prize for best costume, so the bar is always high. I had in my luggage the most exquisite couture hat from Mr. Song, a feathered cap that made me feel like Liza Minnelli. I had perfect makeup: red, red, red lipstick, false eyelashes; everything from the neck up and no costume to go with it. Of course I had to go to the costume store on Saturday morning, the weekend of all the Halloween parties in L.A. I miraculously found a flapper dress and size eleven patent leather tap shoes (I was lucky I didn’t have a fight in the aisle with a drag queen looking for her shoes for the evening).
Mission accomplished; costume complete.

On the way home, we made a quick trip to Costco to get a folding table and some butter. Have you ever gone to Costco with two things on your list? We ran in to the store, and my friends headed for the table while I went for the butter, yelling “No dicking around!” They beat me to the checkout, and we went through the line with just that table and three pounds of butter. Have you ever made it out of Costco with just two items? Not me.

Sunday, I went down to San Diego to visit my dad’s first cousin Marcella Hopkins on the somber occasion of her husband Jack’s death. He was ninety-two years old, and they lived an incredible life. In the house that he himself designed and built with an architect friend in the Frank Lloyd Wright tradition, Jack had a giant map of the world in the hallway with hundreds of of push pins marking the places he and Marcella had visited, from pole to pole and on every continent. They traveled in the Himalayas when they were in their seventies and had to pass a rigorous physical exam before their Sherpa would agree to guide them. They were the first Americans to visit Iran after the revolution; they snuck in.

I had just met Jack and Marcella, their daughter Sylvia, and Marcella’s sister Geraldine the year before. It was a bittersweet reunion on Sunday, with the other two Hopkins daughters, their spouses, husbands, and kids pouring in all day. I got to meet a side of the family that I’d only seen in letters and photographs. That's Geraldine at left, me in the center, and Marcella at right.

Sitting in the driveway was Jack’s 1969 Ford Galaxie 500 station wagon, which had taken the entire family, Mom, Dad, and four kids, to Alaska. The Alaska travel sticker was still in the rear window when Sylvia’s husband, Lee, decided he would slowly restore the car for his father-in-law. Sylvia said, “Whatever you do, do not remove that sticker.”

Lee found a guy on eBay who had old travel stickers, so he removed the worn-out sticker and put the exact replica in its place. When she saw it, Sylvia said, “How did you restore the sticker?” I don’t think he ever told her.

On Monday, I had to go back to L.A., where I was on the jury of the transportation section of the Spark Design Awards. I got to meet some really cool designers, who were not all car designers. Among them was a young woman who was working on a prosthetic leg for children that can be adjusted by the user to accommodate growth, and a man whose design company designed a gel pack that can be dropped in to Third World countries and can completely sanitize raw sewage into drinking water. One helicopter load of these chemical packs is the equivalent of fifteen helicopter loads of bottled water. He told us about it, and it was about tenth on the list of the innovations and designs and projects he and his firm had worked on. I felt kind of small sitting at that table.

So what I did this weekend was have corporate meetings; go to a Halloween party; visit my family; judge a design competition; and then fly home. I picked up Number One Chesapeake Bay retriever Louie from the kennel on my way home from the airport. She seemed a little older, a touch slower, a bit more deaf, but just as happy to see me as ever.
Her acupuncture treatments start this afternoon.
Love, Jean

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text:
2014 Kia Forte EX

Price: $20,315 as tested, including destination
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 173 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/36 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Cooling glove box
Option I can’t live without: Carpeted floor mats ($115) are the only option our test car came with
You might also be considering: Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla

What I Think:

The 2014 Kia Forte is all new for 2014 and offers a host of upgrades from 2013’s model. The car is longer, lower, and wider than previous models, creating a more spacious interior. The new Forte also sports Kia’s Uvo infotainment suite, standard in our EX model, available heated seats, and a standard cooling glove box. The Forte is also eminently affordable. Our top trim level model cost just over $20,000 after destination, which makes it one of a relatively small group of cars that are genuinely affordable for first-time car buyers.

Despite all this, when I took hold of the keys to the Forte I wasn’t expecting to be won over. That’s because, for whatever reason, the Kia brand has never been particularly high on my list. Yes, they’ve got a bunch of interesting, attractive cars. And those hamster commercials are undeniably hilarious. But when I think of cars I’d like to own, I don’t think of Kia.

Still, I kept an open mind as I stepped up to the Forte for the first time. The redesigned exterior features a more aggressive grille and headlight design, as well as some sculpting on the body panels. It’s no supermodel, but these touches are a big improvement over last year’s model. The interior isn’t exactly what you’d call stunning, either; our model featured cloth seats that were already starting to look worn and ratty after just a few thousand miles in the press fleet.

Luckily, leather seat trim is available in the Forte’s Premium package. That package adds a hefty $2,600 to the price of the car, but I’d happily pay extra for the heated leather seating, power sunroof, and push-button start (the Premium package also adds ambient lighting, a six-way adjustable driver’s seat, and an auto-dimming rearview mirror). The Forte’s Technology package also costs $2,600. It adds navigation with HD radio, LED taillights, projector beam headlights, a color LCD driver information display in the dash, and automatic dual-zone climate control.

I was surprised to see that our Forte came standard with Kia’s Uvo infotainment suite. This system gives drivers a small 4.2-inch display with SiriusXM radio capability, a rearview camera, and optional navigation services. The system wasn’t as extensive as those offered by some other automakers, but it was simple and effective and a very good value. Infotainment suites are increasingly common, but it’s still impressive to see one in a car that’s priced below $20,000 before destination.

Driving the Forte felt pretty much like driving any other compact sedan. It’s not exciting, but it’s also not demanding. You can turn the key, point the car toward home, and forget you’re even driving. That’s not what I usually look for in a car, but for someone who just needs four wheels to get them to work and back, the Forte will be exactly right. The 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine makes 173 horsepower, plenty for normal driving. The EPA rates this engine at 36 mpg on the highway and 24 mpg in the city. That’s about middle of the pack (or even a little lower) compared with the Forte’s competition. A 1.8-liter, 148-horsepower four-cylinder, offered on the Forte’s lower LX trim, gets one extra city mile per gallon when outfitted with an automatic transmission.

The Verdict:

I wasn’t expecting to be impressed by or interested in the Forte, but Kia surprised me. This vehicle does a good job of providing drivability, technology, and style in an affordable package. It’s exactly the combination of features that young people buying their first car are looking for. But the Forte’s got a lot of competition. Would I choose a Kia Forte over a Mazda 3 or a Volkswagen Jetta? Probably not. For my money, both of those vehicles are more stylish and more fun to drive. That’s enough to make me cough up for their larger price tags. But there are people out there who will choose the Forte, and they’re not wrong.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Kia Forte looks great, and at $20,315, it makes sense for the pocketbook, too. The price alone may be enough to entice buyers to make the leap from the Volkswagen Jetta or the Honda Civic, which both cost several thousand more. The Forte's modern design beats both of them hands down, and it has a much younger, sportier vibe. I wasn't thrilled with the seats, though; the material seemed cheap, and I couldn't get comfortable.

pageElements.text: Not to be partial, but Jean Knows Cars is a sister publication to the venerable Motor Trend, which has been around since 1949 and handing out Car of the Year awards every year since then. When they’re happy, we’re happy for them.

And we are also very proud when good things happen in Michigan. When we learned that the 2014 Cadillac CTS sport sedan was named Motor Trend Car of the Year, it seemed important to point out that the CTS is built in Lansing, Michigan, as a product of General Motors, the recovering giant that is soldiering on from its downtown Detroit headquarters.
I wonder what car won the very first Car of the Year award in 1949? Hmm, let me look that up… It was a Cadillac.
It’s interesting to note that Motor Trend chose the second-generation CTS as its Car of the Year six years ago, too.

But that’s not to take anything away from the 2014 CTS’s accomplishment in winning a coveted award after being evaluated against a strong field of finalists from around the world. The CTS is an amazing product from a General Motors that has been working at getting better for many years. Lately, they’ve brought out one hit after another.

The CTS is a rear-wheel-drive sport sedan in the best tradition of that genre. Jean calls it “an amazing car from Cadillac, especially in the most aggressive CTS Vsport version [shown here]. It’s every bit the luxury rocket ship that its German rivals are.”
What’s more, it does that while being a thorough all-American that looks like an American car. It doesn’t try to look like a German car, as Jean points out, “other than on the track and the road.”
In announcing the award, Motor Trend editor in chief Ed Loh praised the 2014 model for its “responsive powertrains and masterful balance of smooth ride and sporty handling.”

The 2014 Cadillac CTS starts at $46,025, including destination, and comes with Cadillac’s first use of an eight-speed automatic transmission. The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbo that makes 272 horsepower. A non-turbo 321-horsepower V-6 is an option. Then there's the twin-turbo 420-horsepower V-6 in the CTS Vsport, a version of the CTS that starts just north of $60,000.
Is it hyperbolic to say that Cadillac is back?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: All was quiet on the home front. I didn’t strain the Touareg TDI once I got it home, but I will say that, after a long day at work Friday, it was comforting to be in the familiar interior of a Volkswagen because I own a Jetta TDI wagon. Jumping into the Touareg wasn’t as jarring as it usually is jumping into a brand-new vehicle every night in the dark.

I immediately paired my phone and headed home. I didn’t know it was a TDI when I got in it, but it was so powerful I assumed it might be. There was literally no clue that there’s a diesel engine. No sound, no smell, nothing but a major whack of torque every time you press the accelerator pedal. When I got home, I looked around the back, and there was the logo. I found the Monroney sticker, and sure enough, it has 240 horsepower and a whopping 406 pound-feet of torque, which is that fantastic, dynamic twisting motion that, when you have a lot of it, feels like it’s propelling the car almost out from under your seat.  The horrifying thing on the Monroney was the price. Yes, the Touareg is quite lovely, and this R-Line version included all-wheel drive, a sport suspension, twenty-inch wheels, really gorgeous pebbly black leather seats, a beautiful panoramic sunroof (which, by the way, had a disturbing little rattle this morning all the way to the Interstate), and an extensive list of luxuries, all included in the price. That price, by the way, is $13,720 more than a base Touareg, for a total of $58,560. Holy Moses. I figured $50,000, but almost $60,000? Wow. And then, gulp.

As it turns out, the TDI has a great clean diesel engine and is worth every penny. When you first start the Touareg TDI, it doesn't fire up immediately. The dash gauges light up, and that’s where you see the little glow plug icon, indicating it has a diesel engine, and a split second later, the engine fires up. The glow plug superheats the spark plugs when the engine is cold. (By the way, my husband announced as I was heading to work with the Touareg that he also didn't realize it was a diesel the whole weekend.)

Because I spent the last week sick, I spent all of Saturday recovering from the one and a half days I was at work.  I put a pot roast in the slow cooker, and one of my brothers and his wife came over for dinner and to watch the ’Bama/LSU game. They’re terrible 'Bama fans despite the fact that our relatives live in New Orleans. Such traitors. We played euchre (women whipped the men) and then watched the game in front of a roaring fire. I saw the writing on the wall at the beginning of the third quarter and went to bed. I heard them cheering in the living room.

The wind was blowing like hell all weekend. My husband loved it because all of the leaves were finally blown from the trees except that one last holdout maple in front of the deer camp, and he could spend all Sunday morning blowing them out into the woods.

After that, we used the Touareg to ferry shotguns and black powder rifles to the gun range to sight in their scopes in anticipation of the opening of firearms deer season in Michigan on November 15. Bow hunters have already been out in our woods, but the real national “holiday” (it must be part of the UAW contract here) begins on November 15. The three main freeways feeding into northern Michigan from the lower part of the state are jammed wall to wall on November 14. Because the 15th falls on a Friday, this is going to be a major weekend in northern Michigan, and then the roads will be jammed again all day Sunday and undoubtedly Monday morning with people coming back downstate. If you don’t like seeing carcasses draped across roof racks, you’ll want to stay off the Michigan freeways that weekend.

If you’re a regular visitor to Jean’s Driveway reviews, you’ve seen the hunting camp. It’s that beautiful red barn surrounded by gravel. You can only imagine what the inside of that barn looks like. It’s a 100-year-old granary, and when we moved here, it had a nasty drop ceiling and a mishmash of carpet samples covering the 100-year-old wood floor. There was a broken-down pool table sitting in the middle of it. Over the years, my husband and his friends (and my cousin) have slowly turned it into the Taj Mahal of hunting camps, complete with a granite island, refrigerator, stove, a stovetop nicer than the stovetop in my own home, triple bunks, a potbelly stove, and when they got tired of getting up in the night to feed the stove, they installed a gas wall furnace. Last year, my husband lost his mind and had the 100-year-old barn floor sanded and polyurethaned. He just loved how it looked when they refinished our kitchen floor in the house. That's how he feels about his camp. The camp also has air conditioning so, in the summer, it’s Bob the Show Dog’s kennel to maintain his show-worthy coat, and in fact, Ray the Stray has now decided he prefers the hunting camp to his kennel, so he’s there every day sleeping in the bunks. He has never damaged one thing. I never worry about the alcohol; Bob and Ray are both teetotalers.

Some hunters see hunting season as a chance to drink a lot of odd alcoholic beverages (Jägermeister, Captain Morgan, and the Mason jar of moonshine that came from your cousin in West Virginia). All of those weird bottles seem to congregate at our house, because we have a camp dedicated to our hunter friends, and we don’t drink weird crap. That doesn’t seem to stop them from bringing all the weird crap from their bars to our bar, where it does nothing but collect dust.

Our hunting buddies aren’t big drinkers. In fact, most of them don’t drink at all. So if you imagine a camp with a bunch of guys in red long johns with the flaps hanging down playing cards, smoking cigars, hanging around the fire, eating red meat and lots of junk food, you’re only partially right. They don’t wear red long johns.
Oh, yeah, and they smoke the cigars outside.
A big round oak table is the center of jolly meals (frequently gourmet), card games, and stories about who missed what and why.
I can’t wait till they arrive.

I closed off the night with a visit to my mom, who is eighty-nine but tells everyone where she lives that she’s sixty-four. I asked her once how old she thought I was, and she said thirty-three. I’m going with that. We played Yahtzee and she beat me six out of six games, with a Yahtzee in every game, finishing off with three Yahtzees in the final game, including a one-roller of five fives. How do you compete with this? As far as I’m concerned, she can win every single game and I’ll give her as many rolls and she needs to do it, just to see her flash her rare beautiful smile and slap me five.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text:
2014 Subaru BRZ Limited

Price: $28,390 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 200 horsepower, 151 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 22 city/30 highway
My favorite standard feature: Keyless entry and push-button start
Option I can’t live without: No options on this model
You might also be considering: Honda Civic Si, Mazda MX-5 Miata, Scion FR-S

What I Think:

If these cars look identical to you, it’s not because you’re seeing double. The Subaru BRZ and Scion FR-S are, in fact, almost exactly identical. The cars were designed and engineered as a joint project of Toyota (Scion’s parent company) and Subaru, resulting in these two cars for the North American market and three other nameplates—Toyota 86, Toyota FT-86, and Toyota GT86—in other global markets.

These twins are designed to draw the eye. Low to the ground with aggressive front fascias and rear spoilers, and often dressed in eye-catching colors like Hot Lava and Lightning Red, these cars won’t go unnoticed. I spent a week going back and forth between a Firestorm Red FR-S and a Pearl Blue BRZ, and I got many nods of approval and looks of interest from passers-by. Even a man in a Mercedes-Benz CLS63 AMG—a car with nearly three times the BRZ/FR-S’s 200 horsepower—gave me an enthusiastic thumbs-up and a wave as he passed me on the way home from work.

These cars may impress from the outside, but their interiors aren’t particularly inspiring. The sport seats aren’t very comfortable, and it’s hard to imagine someone of greater than average girth settling in for a long drive. The back seat is too small to be useful on any but the shortest trips, and even then rear passengers will be cramped. The car is so low that it’s difficult to exit gracefully, especially when you’re laden down (as I often am) with a purse, a gym bag, and a stray coffee cup.

None of that really matters, though, because the BRZ and FR-S aren’t supposed to be comfortable or practical. They’re supposed to be sports cars, pure and simple. And they are. These cars are light, exceptionally nimble, and they’ve got rear-wheel drive setups and standard six-speed manual gearboxes. They may not have quite as much power as you’d want, but they’re still a riot to drive.

image.altText: 2014 subaru brz and scion fr s

pageElements.text: For drivers looking for a sport coupe on a budget, the question may not be,  “Should I buy an FR-S/BRZ?” but instead, “Which one should I buy?” Having driven the cars back to back, I can confirm that they feel exactly the same on the road. And they should, considering they’ve got identical engineering and design. The main difference drivers will feel will be in the comfort of the interior space.

The Scion FR-S comes in just one trim level, and our test car came without any add-ons, so we stuck true to the $24,930 asking price (destination included). The interior felt fairly spartan, with no steering wheel controls and a radio that looks like it came from Best Buy. Our BRZ test car came in the top Limited trim level, with Alcantara-trimmed seats, keyless entry and ignition, and a rear deck lid spoiler. Springing for the upper trim level will cost buyers $2,000. Unfortunately, it limped along with the same cheesy stereo we found in the FR-S. Of those options, only the rear spoiler is available in the Scion.

The Verdict:

For many drivers, the Scion FR-S and Subaru BRZ are not good choices. They’re impractical, a little uncomfortable, and refuse to fly under the radar. If that’s not your style, neither are these cars. If, on the other hand, you want a car that you can toss around corners and use to practice rev-matching your downshifts, this could be a match made in heaven. So, which one should you get? Since there’s no difference in driving enjoyment or looks—and, for 2014, both start at similar base prices, $26,390 for the BRZ and $26.010 for the FR-S (including destination charges)—focus on feature availability. If you’re fine with the bare-bones treatment or are tight on cash, the Scion is for you. If you’d like a few more features and a couple of creature comforts, get yourself to a Subaru dealership. Either way, you’re going to end up with a smile on your face.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The BRZ and FR-S are a bit low-slung for this bird, but they are both fun to drive and a perfect match for the buyer who wants a sports car but has a limited budget. Either would make an excellent first car for someone who has spent a lot of time in a go-kart, or wishes they had. And they have airbags.

pageElements.text: This small but mighty Chevrolet is aiming at the youth market with both barrels, and you can tell because of all the electronica: Bluetooth phone connectivity on every model, including Siri Eyes Free compatibility with your iPhone, TuneIn global radio, Pandorda and Stitcher radio apps, and Chevrolet MyLink (optional on LS and LT models, standard on LTZ and RS). After all, 30 percent of Sonic buyers are under age thirty-five and will actually know how to use this connectivity tech. But the Sonic is not just about music and cuteness: it’s the first car in the subcompact class to get the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s five-star overall score for safety, and the 2013 model was also an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick. It has ten airbags! Plus, it’s the only U.S.-assembled subcompact, GM says, so go ahead and look at this for yourself (or your college student).

Available in both four-door sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, the Sonic has a 1.8-liter four-cylinder with a five-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. A 1.4-liter Ecotec turbo is an option on the LT and LTZ models and standard on the sporty RS. It makes a pretty frisky 138 horsepower and comes with a choice of six-speed manual or automatic transmission. Remote start, heated front seats, and a sunroof make the Sonic feel a lot less like a penalty box. And how about the looks? Chevy calls this a “motorcycle-inspired exterior,” I guess because of the round headlamps. For those looking for a sporty Sonic, get the RS. It’s distinguished by a unique grille, a rear spoiler, and a lowered and stiffened suspension, plus an exclusive jet black interior that features a three-spoke leather-wrapped steering wheel with a flat bottom.

pageElements.text: The popular Ford Escape was cute last year. This year, it got sexy. The 2014 model has a smooth, trapezoidal lower grille and a shape that helps it move fluidly. The lines and shape increase aerodynamics ten percent over last year’s model. Just as sexy is the way it opens the rear liftgate for you if you kick your feet under it. Add to that a Class II towing package, and your sexy car will haul 3,500 pounds. Once inside, you can turn on the heated seats, check the cockpit-inspired dash, change the lighting to suit your mood, hit the push button to start, and connect to your tunes and friends through MyFord Touch. This car is loaded with tech toys. In fact, if your own driving isn’t world-class, the Escape will lend a hand. The optional BLIS system will keep an eye on the blind spot and alert you of what’s coming up alongside. The active park assist will take over the parallel parking—and execute it with the accuracy of a machine—so you can park like a pro. Oh, and with up to 32 mpg highway with the EcoBoost engine, you will have more money to spend on your own sexy self.

4. Toyota RAV4

2. Active park assist
3. Blind Spot Information System with cross-traffic alert

pageElements.text: Michelangelo's stint lying on his back on scaffolding, slowly bringing the timeless masterpiece of his Sistine Chapel fresco to life, is one of art history's greatest moments. So it makes sense that Fiat had the inspiration to re-create it, after a fashion. After all, Chrysler or no Chrysler, Fiat is intent on being the most Italian brand on earth, more Italian than Barilla pasta or San Pellegrino mineral water.

So Italian artist Nicola Verlato (right) agreed to spend November 20-25 inside a Fiat 500L, flat on his back, painting a fresco inside it during the Los Angeles Auto Show's public display days. Fiat is calling it the Italian Masterpiece.

The larger Fiat was a good choice, compared with the diminutive regular 500. Nevertheless, Fiat took the precaution of removing the seats, installing a special paint-absorbing fiberglass headliner, and configuring the floor so that Verlato can swivel and change positions while painting lying down.

As to subject matter, luckily, he went with Michelangelo's style rather than something along the lines of the painting of three Michael Jacksons from the artist's website. Verlato used water-based paints for the underlayer of the work and then finished with oils.
What do you think of the result?

pageElements.text: The autumn auto show season is in full swing now, with shows this week in Los Angeles and Tokyo and new car previews as far as the eye can see. We’ll be bringing you updates from Los Angeles all week, but here’s a quick preview of some of the cars we’re looking most forward to.

2014 Porsche Macan

When Porsche started building the Cayenne SUV in 2004, some worried that the company was making a huge mistake. The Cayenne is now by far Porsche’s bestselling model. The brand is hoping to prove naysayers wrong again with the new Macan, a small crossover that shares much of its design language with the Cayenne. The Macan is likely to become Porsche’s most affordable model, so if you’re shopping for a new car, you could unexpectedly find a Porsche within reach, even if it’s not the one you’ve always dreamed about.

2015 Subaru WRX

The 2015 Subaru WRX will make its debut on November 20 (that's tomorrow!), although if you really can’t wait to see what it looks, like there are leaked photos all over the web. The WRX is a souped-up version of the Subaru Impreza and will come with a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine that puts out 268 horsepower. It will be available with a six-speed manual gearbox or a continuously variable transmission. The WRX concept made a big splash with enthusiasts when it premiered at the New York Auto Show last March. We’re confident the finished product will satisfy the Subaru faithful.

2015 Lincoln MKC

Last year, Lincoln’s Los Angeles Auto Show booth featured beautiful classic cars from the brand’s storied past. This year, they're showing us something brand-new: an Escape-based small crossover called the MKC. This will be Lincoln’s second all-new model since its rebranding last year, and early showings of the car have proven it to be both attractive and faithful to the concept version that was shown at January’s Detroit Auto Show.

2015 Jaguar F-type Coupe

Jaguar’s F-type, the brand’s first two-seat sports car in half a century, went on sale this year and captured the hearts of speed fiends everywhere with its rumbling V-8 engine and its modern, aggressive design. But it’s only available as a convertible. What are we Michiganders to do? Well, in case you didn’t give in to lust and buy a droptop if you live in a cold climate, you're in luck: the F-type coupe is here! Jaguar will unveil a closed-top version of the car this week, and from what we can tell based on grainy spy shots and heavily shaded teasers from Jaguar, it’ll be every bit as gorgeous as the cabriolet.

Mercedes-Benz AMG Gran Turismo Concept

Mercedes-Benz and its AMG performance division are using the Los Angeles Auto Show as an opportunity to have a little fun. Instead of unveiling a major redesign or a near-production concept car, AMG will bring its Vision GT concept to Los Angeles. It’s a futuristic supercar with extremely exaggerated proportions, a massive, aggressive-looking grille, and the brand’s trademark gullwing doors. Sadly, you’ll never see this one-off concept on the streets. It’s destined for the digital world, as one of the cars gamers can drive in the new PlayStation 3 game Gran Turismo 6.

And More

Of course, these are far from the only interesting cars at the show. We’re also looking forward to Chevrolet’s new mid-size pickup, the 2014 Colorado; the adorable 2014 Mini Cooper Hardtop; and BMW’s ultra-modern i8, a plug-in hybrid sports car. Stay tuned all week for more updates from the Los Angeles show, and let us know which cars you’re most excited about in the comments below!
